Your name and face will be posted at every garrison. The city is quarantined, there is nowhere you can run.
I'm afraid you have no choice in this matter. You can either help us in this task, or you can rot in jail.
By the laws of the city, I do. These are desperate times, <FirstName>, and I am a desperate man.
From all accounts you are a capable <man/woman>, <FirstName>. Aribeth told me the instructors at the Academy spoke very highly of you.
I do not know what role you are to play in this, <FirstName>. That is for my Lady Aribeth to decide. You must meet her at the Halls of Justice in the coming week.
Lady Aribeth will have more information for you then. Hopefully we'll have a better understanding of what we are up against. We must all do our part, <FirstName>.
Time is of the essence, <FirstName>, although I suppose I can answer a few quick questions.
There is much to attend to in the coming week. Aribeth and I will meet you at the temple. May Tyr's blessing be upon you, <FirstName>.
I am a servant of Tyr, nothing more and nothing less. I serve Neverwinter as is my duty, and my heart weeps as the city suffers.
When Lord Nasher appointed Aribeth to find a cure for the plague, I vowed to stay by my Lady's side throughout the ordeal. We are inseparable.
Aribeth and I are of one heart, it is true. Is this surprising? We are both disciples of Tyr, we are both servants of Neverwinter.
We draw our strength from each other during these difficult times. In duty, in our faith and in our love we will find a way to beat the Wailing Death!
Aribeth is the shining light who must guide our way. She is a paladin of Tyr, and only her courage and devotion to Neverwinter surpass her grace and beauty.
Desther is a good man, though the Wailing Death weighs heavily on him. He does not serve Tyr as my Lady Aribeth or I do, but his devotion to Helm is most admirable.
Desther and his Helmites have been tireless in their efforts to offer what comfort they can to those afflicted by the plague.
I only wish Aribeth and Desther could set aside their personal differences. No matter which god we serve, we must all work together in these troubled times.
Aribeth is the only one who has the authority to speak of such things freely. You will have to talk to her at the Halls of Justice.
Please listen to what I have to say.
All is lost, Fenthick. The nymph has fled; the yuan-ti and the other creatures have escaped into the streets of the city. And where was Aribeth during all this?
Combat Training. Instructor: Herban
Divine Magic Training. Instructor: Elynwyd
Arcane Magic Training. Instructor: Jaroo
Rogue Skill Training. Instructor: Ketta
*Thunk*
You have become a thorn in my side.
Your pathetic life ends here!
You and all of Neverwinter are doomed.
I will crush you beneath my boot.
Kill the Dryad!
No! I must escape!
They've freed the Yuan-Ti!
My bonds are broken, I must escape this place.
Sorry, I didn't mean to interrupt.
Me sorry. Me not mean to interrupt.
I think I'll be going now.
What's your problem? I'm just trying to be friendly.
Me go now.
Why you so mad? Me just want be talk at you.
Why do you want to meet Lady Aribeth so badly?
How's your training going?
I want to ask you a few questions.
Why you want meet Aribeth so bad?
How you training going?
Me want ask you some questions.
What can you tell me about the plague?
Have you heard those rumors about a cure for the plague?
How do you like training here at the Academy?
What you know 'bout plague?
You hear stuff 'bout cure for plague?
You like training at Academy?
I won't take much of your time. I promise.
Me speak at you quick. Me promise me not use much time.
You better answer my questions if you know what's good for you!
You answer me question or you be sorry!
Can't you see I'm practicing my drills? You're a <class>. You should know how hard basic training is. So why are you bothering me?
Can't you see I'm practicing my drills? The Academy might go easy on a <class> like you, but those of us training under Herban can't afford to waste our time chatting!
Back again? I'm pretty busy here - what do you want this time?
Look, I'm not trying to be rude. It's just that Herban doesn't like us taking breaks from our drills. It's a sign of weakness!

I guess I could spare a few minutes for you, but make it quick. I have to finish my drills so I can attend the graduation ceremonies in the south assembly. I don't want to miss my chance to meet Lady Aribeth.
Then I'll get back to my drills.
Get on with it then. The sooner you ask, the sooner I can get back to my training.
Lady Aribeth represents everything the Academy stands for: skill and bravery and honor! She's the reason I joined the Academy in the first place.
She's young, but she's already proved her heroism a dozen times over. That's why Lord Nasher put her in charge of dealing with the plague.
It's not for the faint of heart, that's for sure! Rise at dawn, march for an hour and then an hour of drills. And that's just before breakfast!
Herban doesn't stand for weakness or failure. He drives the recruits hard, but these are tough times. Anyone who can't take it probably shouldn't be training at the Academy anyway.
The training is tough, but the rewards are worth it. Lady Aribeth herself is even here to congratulate the graduating recruits. The chance to meet her in person is inspiration enough for me.
I try not to think about it, to tell you the truth. I need to stay focused on my training. But since you brought it up, there's one thing I don't understand about the Wailing Death.
There's something unnatural about this plague, though it seems nobody wants to admit it. I guess they're afraid of panic in the streets. But you can't deny the facts.
I heard about Blackstaff and his cure. I don't like putting put my faith in wizards, but I heard Lady Aribeth trusts him. She's at the Academy, you know. I hope I get a chance to meet her.
Where did it come from? Neverwinter's the only city that seems to be suffering. And why can't the priests cure it?
Defend the Waterdhavian creatures! Don't let them be taken!
You can't be serious - everybody knows fighting between recruits will get you kicked out of the Academy! Take your blustering threats somewhere else. I've got to get back to my drills.

Merchants Shingle - 1
The image of a flaming hand has been painstakingly dyed into the loose-spun fabric, presumably the symbol of a local wizards' guild.
The simple pennant, crudely painted, is scrawled with gibberish. A red border surrounds it.
The banner depicts a noble blade, shown stark against the purple background. It has the appearance of a warrior's guild crest about it.
A wicked-looking axe has been woven into the hanging tapestry, possibly the emblem of a local barbarian gathering.
Halfling Merc Padded Armor

Elven rangers and warriors are given cloaks like this one to help hide them while patrolling the borders of their land. Each cloak can vary in power, possibly based on the station of the elf who originally wore it.

Armor of this type began to appear in the lands adjacent to Thay after the Year of Smoldering Spells, 1020DR. An irremovable coating of soot has blackened it, dulling noise of movement and making it ideal for stealthy endeavors. Close examination, however, reveals that the charring was not the result of externally applied heat, and suggests the original owner suffered some sort of Thayvian induced combustion. This lends a very morbid feeling to the item.

Someone help me here!
I see them, I think. Our enemy is here.
Time to run, time to run!
You want to pick on somebody?! Come on!
You keep an eye on me, all right? You guard me well.
Hold this spot. This spot right here!
Not good. Can't go much longer.
Eugh! I can taste it... I'm poisoned.

Get in step. Follow me.
Over here. Check this out.
Form up form up! Get ready around me!
Outta the way, all right?
Now, let's pick this lock nice and easy.
Have a good look around. Gotta be something here.
Get down and out! Hide!
I'll get it done.

Someone give me a hand. This is too much to carry.

Good on ya. Hello.
Sure. Yes.
Nope.
Stop!
I want to rest. There, I said it.
I wonder, could we be doing ANY LESS with our time?
Bye then, if that's all.
I gotta say thanks for that, friend.
Well that's... just... dandy!
Woohoo!
I got somthing to say here. Listen up.
That's a pretty good idea there.
Nope, that idea just don't hold water.
Youuuu just watch yourself! I'm warning you!
To your weapons, and don't let up! Attack!
Let's have at it!
Time for a bit of the game!
Rraaaghh!
Patch me up. I need healing.
Little help here!
I have my eye on our enemy here.
This one's lost! Time to leave!
Why don't you come have a try at me!
Watch my back and guard well.
Hold this spot like it was home.
I've life in me yet... I think.
Not good. I think I've been poisoned.
Blasted magics! My spell has had it.
What the... My weapon can't touch 'em!
Step with me. Come on, follow along.
Well, have a look here.
Gather here. Group near me.
One side, now. I need some room here.
This lock needs some tinkering, I think.
Have to take a careful look around this place, I think.
Best get out of sight, and fast, too.
I can do that.
I can't do that.
The task is done.
This load is a bit of a strain.
Well now, what do you want?
Well, hello to you.
I believe so.
I'd say not.
Stop.
I think a bit of a rest is in order.
This is a boring bit of business.
Fare you well, then.
I have to say thanks, I do.
Damnation!
Hooray!
Give a listen here. I need to speak.
That's a fine idea.
I have my doubts about that idea.
You step back, or so help me.... !
By my direction, attack!
No quarter!
Time to die!
To the fight!
Heal my wounds. Now.
I need some help here. Now!
I've got them spotted. Here.
This is not going well. Time to leave!
Here! Fight me! Come on!
You act as guard. Watch my back.
Hold this spot, and don't move.
I'm dying... This is not good.
Ugh... poisoned... damn.
Ugh! My magic has failed!
My weapon... Ineffective? What?
Follow me. Now.
Well, have a look at this here.
Everyone group here. Rally around me.
Move aside, will you?
This lock needs to be dealt with carefully.
Scour this area. It should be closely examined.
Quietly now. Into the shadows.
I can do this.
No, I can't do that.
I'm done with this.
Ugh... This is too much to carry.

Well met. Hello.
I am certain.
I must say no.
Stop.
I need rest. Soon.
I need to get moving. This is a waste of time.
Goodbye.
I appreciate that. Thanks.
By the hells!
Not bad, not bad at all!
I've something to say, here.
That's a good thought. Good idea.
Bad idea. Not good at all.
You just be careful. I'm warning you...
Attack!
Rrraaaaagh!!!
Rip you to shreds!
Nothing walks away!
I need some healing here.
Back me up here. I need a hand!
Got something here! Get ready!
That's it! This fight is lost!
Bring it here! Try me!
Guard me here.
Hold this spot. Don't leave it.
I'm hurt bad... Close to dying.
Ooh... Don't feel well... Poisoned.
Ugh... Blasted spell failure.
Not even a dent! This weapon is useless!
Get in step. Follow me.
Over here. Look at this.
To me! Rally here!
Give me some room. Now.
This lock should be picked before I put my foot through it.
This place needs a thorough search.
Hide! Now!
I can do that.

This crystal appears to be a long, rough prism. Upon utterance of a command word, the crystal emits bright light of one of three sorts.
The first type of light shines as brightly as a torch. The second type of light shines as a very bright ray that can strike and blind a single target. The last type of light shines in a wide beam out from the gem, blinding all targets in the area.

Mischievous and lighthearted, Grigs have no fear of big people and take great joy in playing tricks on them.
Dire Tigers are larger, more vicious versions of their common cousins. They are often found in the company of powerful rangers or druids.
At the same time both savage and maternal, the Gray Render is a deadly predator that often protects weaker creatures within its habitat.
Touched by the evil deity, Iyachtu Xvim, this Hound has undergone a horrible transformation to become an agent of his infernal will.
With their webbed fingers and toes, the tiny Nixies are well suited to their amphibious lifestyle. It's rare to find one far from its lakeshore home.
Talented illusionists and irreverent pranksters, Pixies make their homes in hollowed trees and rocky grottoes, deep within the forests.
With the leathery, bat-like wings and the thirsty persistence of mosquitoes, Stirges rarely attack alone. In large swarms, they can be quite dangerous.
Facing widely held stereotypes of being twisted, devious, or untrustworthy, all Tieflings can trace their bloodline back to some form of fiendish origin.
Devout worshipers of evil, pureblooded Yuan-ti often appear human at first glance. It is only when they draw close that their snake-like features can be seen.

Well, if you ever decide you need a good sorcerer by your side, you know where to find me.
If you can't afford a henchmen, why are you speaking with me? That doesn't make sense, does it? Come on back if you come up with the gold to hire me.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> You're not the only one looking to hire me. It wouldn't be logical for me to cut my rate with demand exceeding supply. My offer stands at 150.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> I guess it's only logical that we should do a little bartering. Besides, I've got a good feeling about you. What if we compromise at 125?
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> There is something to be said for new experiences. Okay, I agree to your terms. 100 gold it is.
Every expedition needs a leader. Since you're paying it's only logical that you should be the one in charge.
I'll use my spells and skills to help you out as we go along as best I can. If you ever want me to change my tactics just speak to me to give me my new instructions.
Since we are both of gnome heritage, I'm willing to join you for only 150 gold pieces.
Sorry, but I'm working for someone else now. There is no point in conversing further.
You're back, so you must need something. The most logical assumption is that you want me to join up with you again. Correct?
Well, if you change your mind you know where to find me... unless someone else hires me, first.
Okay, then let's go. There's an entire world out there waiting for us to discover it.
No matter how many times it happens, I still find being brought back to life one of the strangest experiences I have ever... uh... experienced.
But no damage done. So, what do you say - time for me to join up with you again?
Well, if you change your mind you know where to find me... unless someone else hires me, first.
Okay, then let's go. There's an entire world there waiting for us to discover it!
You're back, <FirstName>. Obviously there must be something you need. Dare I speculate and suggest you are seeking aid in recovering those Words of Power for Aarin Gend?
Greetings, good <man/woman>. Forgive me for being so bold, but you are the one known as <FullName>, aren't you?
My hypothesis was based upon your manner of dress and physical appearance combined with the descriptions of the bards singing the praises of Neverwinter's greatest hero.
Your deeds have earned you quite the reputation, <FirstName>. It is only logical that you should expect strangers to recognize you now.
Now I see why they praise your deeds and not your modesty, <FirstName>. Though I suppose you have earned the right to brag.
Your modesty does not hold true with the facts, <FirstName>. By all accounts your deeds have gone far beyond what might be considered mere duty.
My name is Boddyknock Glinckle, a sorcerer from the island of Lantan. I must admit I am not surprised to see you here.
Given your previous record of service it was only logical to conclude that you would be among those recruited by Neverwinter's spymaster to aid his cause.
Farewell, <FirstName>. If you require the services of a talented sorcerer you know where to find me.
Aarin has hired on dozens of mercenaries to aid him in this cause. I came to Neverwinter to chronicle and study the Wailing Death and I have been following events quite closely ever since.
Being of a curious and analytical mind I have to admit the deepening mystery of the Wailing Death and who is ultimately behind it to be quite intriguing.
I believe that recovering the Words of Power will provide us with the answers we seek. That is why I agreed to help Aarin Gend in this quest.
I am an accomplished sorcerer but my skills can hardly measure up to a hero such as yourself. The risk for me to search for the Words on my own would be far too great.
But I am eager to look into this matter in greater detail. Perhaps I could accompany you, <FirstName>, and put my formidable skills at your disposal.
I would be honored to join up with you, <FirstName>. Together we can find the Words of Power and hopefully solve the mystery of who was truly behind the Neverwinter plague.
I doubt I can help you there, <FirstName>. All I know of this area is limited to the accounts of Lantanese explorers detailing the hills to the north of Beorunna's well.

As you know the love of exploration and the thrill of discovery are traits shared by all the people of Lantan. Whenever one of our people visits a foreign land they make an account of all they experience.

These accounts are added to the Great Library of Lantan so that all our people can be enlightened. A few years ago a gnome named Herigo Wanderlust returned to my island with his account of this region.
The majority of his time was spent exploring the hills to the north of Beorunna's Well, secretly observing the habits and activities of the giants who make their home there.
Oh, yes. We have no giants on Lantan, so my people are fascinated by them. Herigo's research is the most detailed account we have had to date of these remarkable creatures.

The subjects he was studying - hill giants were the exact species, if I remember correctly - had actually chosen a king from among their numbers, and this king had united several bands of giants into a single powerful tribe.

They had even constructed a great steading to house the king, and from there they raided the lands to the south. Until Herigo's research we assumed hill giants to be incapable of such high level organization.
Most of Herigo's research was of a scientific nature - diet, mating habits, activity cycles, habitat and territory range. Academically compelling, but hardly useful in your mission, I'm afraid.
I would love to see these giants before I leave the North, <FirstName>, though I know my own wants must be set aside until after the Words of Power are found.
Hello, <FirstName>. It is I, Boddyknock Glinckle. It is good to see a friendly face in these unfamiliar surroundings.
I have given you no reason to insult me, <FirstName>. I find your reaction... illogical.
I will not subject myself to such irrational behavior. If you find your reason returns, come speak with me again.
I have to admit I am not surprised to find you here at Beorunna's Well, <FirstName>.
Given your previous record of service it was only logical to conclude that you would be among those recruited by Neverwinter's spymaster to aid his cause.
That is partly why I chose to come here, <FirstName>. I have found our previous experiences together to be very... enlightening.
Then I will bid you farewell, <FirstName>. If you require the services of a talented sorcerer you know where to find me.
I would be honored to join up with you once more, <FirstName>. Together we can find the Words of Power and solve the mystery of who was truly behind the Neverwinter plague.
I doubt I can help you there, <FirstName>. All I know of this area is limited to the accounts of Lantanese explorers detailing the hills to the north of Beorunna's well.

As you know the love of exploration and the thrill of discovery are traits shared by all the people of Lantan. Whenever one of our people visits a foreign land they make an account of all they experience.

These accounts are added to the Great Library of Lantan so that all our people can be enlightened. A few years ago a gnome named Herigo Wanderlust returned to my island with his account of this region.
The majority of his time was spent exploring the hills to the north of Beorunna's Well, secretly observing the habits and activities of the giants who make their home there.
Oh, yes. We have no giants on Lantan, so my people are fascinated by them. Herigo's research is the most detailed account we have had to date of these remarkable creatures.

The subjects he was studying - hill giants were the exact species, if I remember correctly - had actually chosen a king from among their numbers, and this king had united several bands of giants into a single powerful tribe.

They had even constructed a great steading to house the king, and from there they raided the lands to the south. Until Herigo's research we assumed hill giants to be incapable of such high level organization.
Most of Herigo's research was of a scientific nature - diet, mating habits, activity cycles, habitat and territory range. Academically compelling, but hardly useful in your mission, I'm afraid.
I would love to see these giants before I leave the North, <FirstName>, though I know my own wants must be set aside until after the Words of Power are found.
Well met, <FirstName>. It is I, Boddyknock Glinckle from the island of Lantan. I trust you remember me from our last meeting.
When I heard Aribeth was recruiting people to aid in the search for the cult behind the Wailing Death it was a simple logical leap to assume you would joining us.
Greetings, good <man/woman>. Forgive me for being so bold, but you are the one known as <FullName>, aren't you?
Ah, forgive me then. I will have to go back and reevaluate the data I was basing my assumption on.

My hypothesis was based upon your manner of dress and physical appearance combined with the descriptions I have heard from those praising the <man/woman> responsible for saving Neverwinter from the Wailing Death.
Now I understand why they praise your abilities, and not your modesty.
Your modesty is admirable, but the facts cannot be denied. Others may have been involved, but everyone is in agreement that you played a particularly crucial role.
I am Boddyknock Glinckle, a gnome sorcerer from the island of Lantan. I must confess that I am not surprised to find you here, <FirstName>.
When I heard Aribeth was recruiting people to aid in the search for the cult behind the Wailing Death it was a simple logical leap to assume you would be among us.
Farewell, <FirstName>. If you find yourself requiring the services of a good sorcerer you can find me here... unless my services are contracted by someone else.
What an odd thing to say. I have already established the fact that we both work for Lady Aribeth. What possible reason could you have for bringing the matter up a second... oh, I see.

Forgive me. My nature is to be observant, yet I did not immediately notice your... condition. However, the facts of the situation are made more than clear by the unsightly drool dangling from your chin.
I was in Neverwinter to study the plague - its causes and effects - so that such a catastrophe might be prevented in the future.
You may have discovered a cure for the plague and flushed out those behind it, <FirstName>, but the process by which the Wailing Death was spawned has not yet been determined.
I am eager to solve that mystery, if only so such a horror can never be unleashed upon the world yet again. But that can only be accomplished if we first locate the cult.

I have heard people claiming the cult has a base in the plains to the south, others insist there is undeniable evidence of the cult in the forests to the east, still others swear the cult is hiding in the city of Luskan to the north.

Obviously such rumors and hearsay are of little value. I prefer to put my faith in hard, empirical evidence - evidence I can observe with my own two eyes. As yet, I have found no evidence I consider reliable.
I don't think you understand. Without the proper data to analyze my evaluation of the situation would result in a hypothesis with an unacceptable margin of error.
Naturally I have formed some preliminary theories, but if I were to venture any opinion on this matter it would be nothing more than a complete and utter guess.

A... a hunch? You are a strange <man/woman>, <FirstName>. But I suppose if I were forced to make a... <StartAction>shudder</Start>...guess I would say we should start our search in the Neverwinter Wood, to the south east of Port Llast.

Roots, herbs and other flora grow in abundance in the forest, many of which can be used to heal a variety of illnesses. It is only logical to assume such plants can also be used to bring sickness and death.
Plus the woods are shunned by most civilized people - they believe they are haunted - making it a perfect place for a secret hideout for a large group.

The Neverwinter Wood seems to be the only place that provided the seclusion and the materials that would have been necessary for the cult to bring about the Wailing Death. At least, that's my best guess.

I am an accomplished sorcerer, <FirstName>, but I also have a realistic understanding of my own limitations. Surviving the wilds of this region alone would be a challenge that surpasses my capabilities.
Besides, Aribeth has hired us so that we may serve and assist others who are more suited for heroism and great deeds.
You are a well known hero, <FirstName>. If I were to accompany you I am certain my skills would be of some use.
Then I will be glad to join your cause, <FirstName>. It is an honor to serve with a hero such as you.
I will follow you and perform to the best of my abilities, according to the orders you have given me. Any time you wish to issue new orders you have only to speak to me again.
As I said, I had a preliminary hypothesis. However, I would not be at all surprised to find my theory about the Neverwinter Wood to be wrong.
Good to see you again, <FirstName>, though in actual fact I cannot say I am really surprised.
When I heard Aribeth was recruiting people to aid in the search for the cult behind the Wailing Death it was a simple logical leap to assume you would be one of those recruited.
I am *not* stalking you, <FirstName>! I have a vested, scientific interest in investigating the Wailing Death and the events that transpired in Neverwinter.
When we parted ways, <FirstName>, I meant to continue my explorations of the North. But then I heard Aribeth was recruiting mercenaries to join in the search for the cult behind the plague.
You may have discovered a cure for the plague and flushed out those behind it, <FirstName>, but the process by which the Wailing Death was spawned has not yet been determined.
Given my scientific interest in this plague, and my desire to ensure it is never again unleashed upon Faerun, it was only logical that I answer Aribeth's call for aid.
Farewell, <FirstName>. If you find yourself in need of a sorcerer you know where to find me... until someone else hires my services.
When Aribeth recruited the mercenaries we were all paid in advance for our services - well paid. Lord Nasher is sparing no expense in tracking down these cultists.
Our instructions were simply to make ourselves available to whomever requires our assistance. So, in that spirit, is there anything I can do for you?
You are back, <FirstName>. That would lead me to conclude that you require some assistance from me. How can I be of service to you?
My knowledge of the city is somewhat limited, as I have not been here very long. My arrival coincided precisely with the closing of the gates and quarantine of the city.
I came in the name of scientific curiosity, to catalog and study this newly discovered plague that had broken out in the North.
I concluded that the most logical place to begin my investigations of the Wailing Death was in the Beggar's Nest.
Hello there, my good <man/woman>. You don't have the look of one of those Neverwinter soldiers about you, neither do you show any evidence of having contracted the plague.
But you have a certain bearing about you that distinguishes you from the ordinary citizen. Based on my observations I'd venture the hypothesis that you are an adventurer, correct?
Then there's no logical reason to continue this conversation, is there? But if you find yourself in need of a good sorcerer come speak to me again.
I am Boddyknock Glinckle, a gnome sorcerer from the island of Lantan who has only recently arrived here in Neverwinter.
I left my home some time ago to experience the broader world. It is not uncommon for the people of my island to undertake such a journey.

I was exploring the northern Sword Coast when I heard rumblings of a previously unknown plague breaking out in Neverwinter. In the name of scientific discovery I came to investigate and catalog the new illness.
Fortunately I arrived before the city was quarantined. I decided to begin my investigations of the Wailing Death in the Beggar's Nest.
From the accounts I gathered, it was generally agreed that the Beggar's Nest was where the outbreak began. I thought the best way to learn about the plague was to trace it back to its source.
And when I learned the clerics were unable to combat the plague I thought that I could apply the scientific principles of Lantan to discover a more mundane cure.
Unfortunately I had to end my investigations into the Beggar's Nest mere days after they began. Far too short a time to conduct a proper study of the situation.
Your mission? And what mission would that be, exactly?
Yes, I suppose extracting a cure from certain reagents could be a possible method of countering the rapid spread of this epidemic.
Given my own scientific interest in the plague I would be glad to accompany you in your mission, <FirstName>.
A confidential mission from Lady Aribeth? Given the circumstances it is not difficult for me to surmise that your mission is somehow connected to finding a cure for the plague.
It is difficult to conduct a serious scientific analysis when you are constantly beseiged by zombies. Much as I wanted to continue my research, I was not about to throw my life away to do it.

However, the zombie infestation struck me as more than mere coincidence. I suspect there may be more than a casual relationship between the animated corpses in the district and the outbreak of the plague itself.
While the zombies continue to wander the district I cannot test my theory, but I suspect information that could lead to a cure can be found within the Beggar's Nest.
The Lantanese people do not disparage magic, though many do not understand it. However, in my land we rely on the arcane far less than the other peoples of Faerun.
We prefer to seek a scientific solution to a problem rather than a magical one. Often through observation and experimentation a problem can be solved without resorting to mage-craft.

Of course, sometimes a little touch of the arcane is a good thing. When the situation is appropriate I do not hesitate to use my powers, <FirstName>. I may be from Lantan, but I am first and foremost a sorcerer.
As a practitioner of arcane magic yourself you must surely have encountered the suspicion and fear with which most common folk regard our art. My homeland is not so different.
My homeland does have a reputation for producing marvelous machines and outlandish contraptions not otherwise known in Faerun.
We Lantanese are a people guided by the analytical principles of science: observation, reason and logic. But don't allow yourself to be misled by rumors and hearsay.
We aren't all kooky inventors as some would have you believe. I myself am a sorcerer, for example.
Is there something you need, <FirstName>?
As you wish.
My skills have improved somewhat. Give me a few seconds to rest and I shall be ready to show you my new skills.
It's always good to have a plan, and it's even better to keep working at it until it's right. What would you like to change?
How far away do you want me to stay?
It wouldn't make sense to continue this partnership if you are unhappy. Are you sure you want me to leave?
Your actions are rather illogical. You say you want me to go, then you tell me to stay. Very strange.
I will stay by your side, however I hope your unpredictable and irrational behavior doesn't continue.
Then I guess the only logical thing for us to do is split up for now. But I'll remain here in case you decide you have need of me again.
It would be foolish to enter combat without having a well thought out plan of attack. What would you like to change?
Very well, I will no longer attempt to open locked doors or chests.
Very well, I will open any locked door or chest that you fail to open.
Very well, I will no longer travel in stealth mode.
Very well, I will travel in stealth mode from now on.
Very well, I will search whenever we are moving.
Very well, I will no longer search while we are moving.
Of course. How soon would you like me to heal you?
I shall do as you have asked.
At what distance do you want me to stay?
Very well, I shall stay a reasonably far distance away from you whenever possible.
Very well, I shall stay a medium distance away from you whenever possible.
Very well, I shall stay reasonably close to you whenever possible.
Was there anything else?
Is there anything else?
I am a staunch proponent of the free exchange of ideas, <FirstName>. What is it you wish to know?
Then we should get back to your mission.
I doubt I can help you there, <FirstName>. All I know of this area is limited to the accounts of Lantanese explorers detailing the hills to the north of Beorunna's well.

As you know the love of exploration and the thrill of discovery are traits shared by all the people of Lantan. Whenever one of our people visits a foreign land they make an account of all they experience.

These accounts are added to the Great Library of Lantan so that all our people can be enlightened. A few years ago a gnome named Herigo Wanderlust returned to my island with his account of this region.
The majority of his time was spent exploring the hills to the north of Beorunna's Well, secretly observing the habits and activities of the giants who make their home there.
Oh, yes. We have no giants on Lantan, so my people are fascinated by them. Herigo's research is the most detailed account we have had to date of these remarkable creatures.

The subjects he was studying - hill giants were the exact species, if I remember correctly - had actually chosen a king from among their numbers, and this king had united several bands of giants into a single powerful tribe.

They had even constructed a great steading to house the king, and from there they raided the lands to the south. Until Herigo's research we assumed hill giants to be incapable of such high level organization.
Most of Herigo's research was of a scientific nature - diet, mating habits, activity cycles, habitat and territory range. Academically compelling, but hardly useful in your mission, I'm afraid.
I'm afraid I can't really tell you anything more, <FirstName>. We should probably continue on with the search for the Words of Power in any case.
I have heard many rumors about where the cult might be hidden, <FirstName>, but I have gathered no hard evidence yet to support my theories.
If I were to tell you my hypothesis now, in the absence of any empirical data, I fear it would be nothing but a complete and utter guess.
A... a hunch? I don't think you understand. Without the proper data to analyze my evaluation of the situation would result in a hypothesis with an unacceptable margin of error.

But I suppose I am in your service, <FirstName>. If you demand a <StartAction>...shudder...</Start> guess, then I would say we should start our search in the Neverwinter Wood to the south east of Port Llast.

Roots, herbs and other flora grow in abundance in the forest, many of which can be used to heal a variety of illnesses. It is only logical to assume such plants can also be used to bring sickness and death.
Plus the woods are shunned by most civilized people - they believe they are haunted - making it a perfect place for a secret hideout for a large group.

The Neverwinter Wood seems to be the only place that provided the seclusion and the materials that would have been necessary for the cult to bring about the Wailing Death. At least, that's my best guess.
Remember, <FirstName> - this theory is based entirely on speculation and can hardly be considered sound. The only way to test its veracity is to search the Neverwinter Wood for ourselves.
My knowledge of the city is quite limited, <FirstName>. My arrival virtually coincided with the quarantine of Neverwinter.

As for the plague itself, I was hoping to discover a cure - or at least a way to prevent the plague from spreading. I have a theory of how this might be accomplished, if you are interested in hearing it.

With most plagues fatality rates are extremely high, but there always a few who defy the odds and survive even after contracting the illness. Something within these individuals resists the symptoms of the disease.
If we could isolate this characteristic of the surviving subjects we might be able to reproduce or transfer it to other organisms, conferring an immunity to the disease in question.

Unfortunately I have yet to locate a single individual who has contracted this particular plague and survived. However, I would like to continue my examinations of the Beggar's Nest before I admit this problem has no solution.
All the accounts I have gathered of the plague are in agreement that the outbreak of the Wailing Death began in the Beggar's Nest.
Logically the best chance of locating a survivor is to trace this epidemic back to its source. I would not be surprised to discover a few survivors of the Wailing Death in the Beggar's Nest district.
Then we should continue with your mission.
Eager as I am to conduct my research into the plague, I am not so obsessed as to throw away my life. The Beggar's Nest is all but overrun with zombies!
Incidentally, the zombie infestation in the Beggar's Nest struck me as more than mere coincidence. I suspect the animated corpses might be somehow linked to the outbreak of the plague itself.
Of course I was unable to test this theory, as my chances of survival on my own in a district overrun with zombies were virtually negligible.
Perhaps I will speak more of this later, but now is not the time. We need to focus on our mission. We have to get those Words of Power back to Aarin Gend.
Do not fear, <FirstName>. As long as you seek the Words of Power I shall remain in your service.
In my time with you I have seen more wonders and experienced more fantastic adventures than all but a handful of my people. When I return home my accounts will enrich the knowledge of all Lantan.
I would be a fool to leave you now even if I thought I could find a dragon scale on my own.
Never fear, <FirstName>. I understand the importance of your mission, and I will not pu my own needs ahead of it. That would be illogical.
Nothing would please me more, <FirstName>. Except for locating the Words of Power for Aarin Gend.
Yes - this is exactly what I was looking for. The priests of Gond will be amazed when I return with this wondrous material!
Yet again you have proven yourself to be the greatest of friends, <FirstName>. Here, take this ring. It was given to me by the clerics of the Wonderbringer before I left Lantan.
You have aided and guided me throughout my sojourn in the service of the Gond's church. The logical thing to do would be to give the church's ring to the <man/woman> who aided me on my mission.
The ring has powerful magical properties which you must not underestimate. Now that I have fulfilled my quest I have no further need of the ring.
Eventually I will return to Lantan and present the dragon scale to Gond's church, the prism blossom seeds to my father and the leaven bread to my master.
I suspect it will be a most joyful home coming - I will be hailed as a hero among my people. And it is all because of you, <FirstName>.
After all you have done for me I can hardly leave you now, <FirstName>. No, the only rational course of action would be to stay with you until your own mission is done.
My return to Lantan will have to wait until we find the Words of Power and return them to Aarin Gend. As long as you search for the Words I will stay by your side, <FirstName>.

I probably shouldn't tell you this, <FirstName>. But you have proven yourself to me many times over, and I am certain not even Gond himself would begrudge me for asking your assistance in this matter.
I am about to reveal a secret known only to the people of Lantan and those within the church of Gond Wonderbringer. I am relying on you not to spread this secret around.

As you know, <FirstName>, I left Lantan on a journey of discovery. What you might not have known was that my journey is also a holy pilgrammage in the service of Gond Wonderbringer. I have been charged with a task.
I will not force you to aid me in this, <FirstName> - though I fear I will not succeed without your help. If you change your mind speak to me again. In the meantime, let us return to our mission.

Whenever one of my people embarks upon a sojourn to the mainland the clerics of Gond pray to the Wonderbringer for a vision of what new and previously unseen wonder the traveler is to seek out on his journey.

In my case the priests saw a terrible creature of enormous size and great power - a monster unknown in my homeland. Only after consulting the texts in the great library did the priests understand the vision was of a dragon.
Obviously bringing back an entire dragon would be an impossible request, and the clerics would have been foolish to burden me with such a ridiculous task.
Instead, they charged me to return with a dragon's scale. Through experimentation, study and magical divination we can learn much about these creatures from a single scale.
However, the scale must not have been tainted by spells or other unnatural forces such as magical weapons, or the experiments will be corrupted by the outside influence.
I realize the odds of defeating a dragon without spells or magical weapons are so minute as to be negligible. However,there may be another way to obtain the scale.
Dragons occasionally come into conflict with other creatures - giants and other dragons, primarily. In battling these foes surely a dragon must be wounded - perhaps even killed.

Logically we might expect to find a dragon scale that has been torn free or dislodged in one of these struggles. This is far more likely than killing a dragon ourselves without any magical aid whatsoever.
You seem quite interested in this subject, <FirstName>. I suppose we could spare a few minutes from our quest to speak about Gond's arrival on the shores of Lantan, if you wish.

Precisely. As I already mentioned, Gond Wonderbringer appeared on the shores of Lantan during the Time of Troubles. During those years Ao, the overfather of the Gods, decreed they must walk among us as mortals.
Gond Wonderbringer chose to take the form of a gnome - a logical choice, given the obvious advantages of my race. It was in this form that he washed up on the shores of Lantan.
As you can imagine people were skeptical of Gond's claim, but the Wonderbringer's clerics confirmed his identity.
During the Time of Troubles there was great strife among the suddenly mortal gods. Bane, Bhaal and Myrkul slew each other battling over the portfolio of death.
Waukeen, goddess of wealth and commerce, vanished and has never returned. But Gond chose not to become involved in the machinations and power struggles of the other deities.
He dwelt peacefully among the people of my island home, sharing his wisdom and knowledge with us. Perhaps the most well known gift he shared with us was the secret of making smokepowder.
Smokepowder is quite useful, if somewhat dangerous. Though it resembles nothing more than coarse black sand, when lit smokepowder will explode with a blast of surprising force.
Smokepowder is a remarkable tool with many uses, but it can be quite destructive in the wrong hands. This is why even among the Lantanese the secrets of smokepowder are known only to a precious few.
But even though smokepowder is Gond's most well known gift to my people, it was not the most important piece of knowledge he shared with us.
As I have already told you, we are a society of observers and thinkers. We have a tradition of isolating ourselves from the politics and events of Faerun. But Gond changed all that.
He warned us a time was coming when we must become involved in the affairs of the mainland. A time was coming in which we could not afford to remain dispassionate and neutral.
He would not say when this time was or what the circumstances would be of this momentus event. But when a god tells you to go forth into the rest of the world, you would be wise to listen.
Given the analytical nature of our society you could not expect we would suddenly integrate ourselves with the rest of Faerun without careful study and research of what we were about to undertake.

Suddenly the discoveries and accounts of those who had left our island on journeys of exploration became infinitly more important as a tool to teach us of the society and culture we knew we would soon be interacting with.
Now, by law, all who leave Lantan must first visit the clerics of Gond Woderbringer to obtain divine guidance before embarking on their journey.
Me? Uh... you know, the usual. Go with Gond, that kind of thing. Pretty much what you'd expect.
The guidance I received from Gond's clerics is a personal and private thing, <FirstName>. And it has nothing to do with our work for Aarin Gend.
Aribeth's betrayal has caused me no amount of confusion, <FirstName>. On the one hand, her actions appear irrational and illogical - she has vowed to destroy the city she spent her life protecting.
But on the other hand, isn't it logical to assume a warrior will want to avenge the death of her lover? And what about Fenthick's death, which caused this whole mess?
His execution made no sense. He was not an enemy of the city and had he lived he would have done everything in his power to help Neverwinter to make up for what he had done.
What purpose is there in killing a man who is only going to be your ally in the future? Such irrational behavior is difficult for me to understand, <FirstName>.
In Lantan we bow to the laws of reason and logic. Emotion can never be truly factored out of any decision, but we do our best to look at the facts with a dispassionate eye before taking action.

I suppose in that sense we are quite different from many of the other cultures of Faerun. We will have to familiarize ourselves with these strange lands if we hope to integrate Lantan into mainland society.
Lantan is an island, by geography we are isolated from the rest of the world. Over the centuries this has led to an insular culture - particularly among my people, the gnomes.

We consider ourselves safely removed from the troubles of the mainland. We have been fascinated observers of the history of Faerun, as befits our analytical mindset. But we chose not to be active participants in events.

Recently, however, our culture has embarked upon a radical journey of change, a revolutionary shift in our entire belief system. Soon, perhaps even in my own lifetime, Lantan will become an important part of life in the Realms.

We are thinkers, inventors and academics, <FirstName> - not soldiers. We plan to bring our culture and beliefs to Faerun through peaceful means - though we are proceeding in a rational and logical fashion.

Before we attempt to introduce ourselves into the existing order we must study and analyze the current political and cultural realities in an organized and thorough fashion. Could you expect anything less, given our nature?
As you can imagine a revolution of this magnitude must be precipitated by an astonishing event. Without a significant catalyst there cannot be a significant reaction.
In our case the catalyst is a single wondrous event - the day the god Gond Wonderbringer washed up on the shores of Lantan in mortal form.
You are right, <FirstName>; I am speaking of the Time of Troubles, when the gods were forced to take mortal form and walk among us.
You have not heard of the Time of Troubles, <FirstName>? The days when the gods were forced to take mortal form and walk among us?
I would share the tale with you, but the story of Gond Wonderbringer's time on Lantan is a long one, <FirstName>.
Perhaps later I will be in a mood to speak more of my tale, but for now we should focus on your mission. The cult responsible for the Wailing Death must be found.
I will not abandon the search for the cultists behind the plague; I have pledged to aid you in destroying those who released the foul taint of the Wailing Death.
But part of me is hoping that in our journeys we will be lucky enough to stumble across the crystalline seeds of the prism blossom.
Don't worry, <FirstName>. As much as I want to reconcile with my father, I understand that our mission is far more important. It would be illogical for me to let my own quest interfere with yours.
You are a true friend, <FirstName>. With you by my side I'm certain we will somehow find the seeds of the prism blossom... if they still exist.
Let me see... yes, these seeds do seem to be made of glass. And their shape and size are consistent with the accounts in the travel diary. You have done it, <FirstName>!
When I present these to my father he is certain to forgive me! Thank you, <FirstName> - but I am afraid the only reward I have to give is my thanks.
Although I have no reward to repay you, <FirstName>, there may yet be some benefit to you for aiding me in this quest.
Lantanese artifiacts draw their energy from the thrill of discovery and the wonder of exploration. This remarkable discovery may have augmented the powers of the ring I gave you earlier.

In any case, I thank you once again, <FirstName>. But I will not leave your side yet. Only after we have located the cult behind the Wailing Death will I return to my homeland and present these seeds to my father.
The pain of what happened with my father, of how I destroyed the garden he had spent a lifetime cultivating, is a very personal pain, <FirstName>.

But you have proved yourself to be a good friend - after all, it was you who helped me find the leaven bread. I suppose it is only logical to expect you might be able to help me with my father as well.
I suppose you are right, <FirstName>. This is a family matter, though I fear without your help I may never be able to heal the breach between my father and myself.
I will stay by your side as we continue to search for the cult behind the Wailing Death, though if you decide you are willing to help me in this I would ask you to speak to me again.
I know I can never replace the many varieties of plants and flowers that were once in my father's garden, but perhaps if I make a grand gesture he will find it in his heart to forgive me.
Throughout my father's life there has been one flower he has longed to see more than any other, but one which he has never been able to acquire.
Among the great library of Lantan there are accounts of the prism blossom; a living, growing flower whose petals are said change color and reflect light as they were made of crystal.
The account of the flower occurs in only one text - the travel diary of an explorer who died several centuries ago after returning from a journey to the North.
No one has ever been able to locate this rare flower or its gleaming crystal seeds, though many have spent a lifetime searching for it.
It may be the prism blossom is only a myth, <FirstName>, but if I could find the seeds of this flower and give them to my father, I am certain he would forgive me for destroying his garden.
This is difficult for me to speak of, <FirstName>. What happened between my father and I... our falling out... is a painful memory.
But maybe if I share the tale with someone else I can ease some of the pain and guilt I feel over what happened. That is a logical assumption, isn't it?
My father's days of ground breaking research in agronomy are behind him, he is an old man content to putter in his own garden, happily living out his days among his friends and family.
But even so he still receives gifts of strange and exotic plants from distant lands so that he can add them to his garden.
It is said that in spring when the flowers bloom my father's yard is the most beautiful place on Lantan. It truly is his pride and joy.
I wish that had been the only consequences of my actions, <FirstName>. My father asked me to tend his garden for a few weeks while he went to visit a friend on the other side of the island.

Everything went well the first week. I found the work enjoyable enough, though hardly as stimulating as my sorcerer's studies. I even came up with a more efficient watering system he could use on his plants.
But in the second week I noticed the beginning of a rot weed infestation.
I do not blame myself for the rot weed, <FirstName> - only in how I handled the infestation.
Rot weed is a vile, noxious crawling vine with a foul, pungent odor. Unchecked it will overrun any garden in a matter of weeks, choking the life from every other plant.

Even worse, the roots release a powerful toxin into the earth, poisoning the soil so nothing else will grow on the land for years. And, like most unwanted garden guests, rot weed is virtually impossible to kill.

The only way to deal with rot weed is through fire applied directly to the vines. If you can make the fire hot enough, the flames will be absorbed into the plant and burn down to the root, killing the weed.

I still remember my father as a child using oil and torches to destroy a rot weed infestation - it was long and difficult work, for the vine is resistant to fire and it is difficult to make the flames hot enough to wither the roots.
However, I had no such worries as I went out to the garden that morning. The infestation had only just begun, and I had a secret weapon. After all, I was a sorcerer.
With visions of how pleased my father would be at the efficiency of my methods, I approached the weed and unleashed a burning hands spell directly at the vine.
I made the mistake of appoaching the problem without all the necessary data. My actions were logical in the context of my knowledge, but I was operating under a fatally flawed assumpton.

There was a reason my father used oil and torches to eliminate the infestation, rather than sending for the local mage. Magical fire destroys rot weed but the intense heat causes the plant to violently explode.

The vine burst, spewing out molten sap that ignited everything it touched. The roots ignited in the earth and columns of flame erupted from the soil, raining blazing bits of vegetation down all around me.
Miraculously I was unharmed by the conflagration, though the entire garden was soon ablaze. As was my father's house. And the houses of our neighbors on either side.
No one was injured, and for that at least I am grateful. But by the time the fire brigade doused the flames all three houses were ruined - and my father's prize winning garden was nothing but ash.
Your callous mockery of my pain is as cruel as it is unnecessary. I cannot understand the pleasure you take in the suffering of others.
I refuse to discuss this with you anymore, <FirstName> - not while you are in such a cruel and spiteful frame of mind! Let us just return to the mission at hand.
It may have been an accident, <FirstName>, but that does nothing to mitigate the cost of the terrible tragedy.
I am well aware of the terrible nature of my tragedy, <FirstName>, and what cost it had on my father.

My father is a wealthy man, so he did not begrudge me the compensation he had to pay to his neighbors or the cost of replacing his own home. But his garden was utterly destroyed, and for that he has never forgiven me.
Maybe... mabye someday I can make it up to him, <FirstName>. Some gesture to heal the pain I have caused him.
Please... I don't wish to discuss this any longer. The memory is too painful.
As you know, I come from Lantan - an island renowned for its inventions and scientific advances. From that you can rightly conclude that I myself am of an analytical and curious nature.
You also know I am a sorcerer, and from that you can no doubt draw further conclusions - though in all truth my chosen profession is rather uncommon among the Lantanese culture.
The mysteries of the arcane are not as eagerly sought out in my homeland as they are in other places. We have inventions to accomplish many of the things others rely on magic to perform.
In my homeland there is no shame attached to what I do. It is merely seen as unusual, though I will admit it is not the future my father envisioned for me.
I was his eldest son, and I suppose my father wanted me to follow in his own footsteps. But flowers, plants and gardens never held much interest for me.

Agronomy is a well respected field in Lantan, and my father was one of the finest horticulturalists on the island. His pioneering research in cross-pollination and grafting techniques was responsible for the creation of twenty-six unique species of plants.

Because of my father's work Lantan's agricultural yields increased, as did the island's supply of medicinal herbs. And the beauty and variety of our flowering species is unparalleled anywhere on the mainland.
I can see no logical reason for this hostility, <FirstName>. Neither can I see a reason why I should subject myself to it.
Given your present mood, I see no point in continuing this conversation right now.
A finer gnome could not be found the length and breadth of Faerun, <FirstName>. I suppose that is why I find the gulf that has grown between us so painful to accept.
My father and I had a... a falling out. Please, <FirstName>, this is difficult for me to speak of. I... I am not sure I wish to discuss this with you right now.
Do not underestimate the value of agricultural research, <FirstName>. It may lack the excitement of adventuring, but the growing and tending of plants can be quite useful.
Druids worship nature, <FirstName>. But we in Lantan seek to control and direct nature; to extract that which is useful and remove that which is harmful.
Ask me about this again later, <FirstName>, and I will be happy to continue my tale. But for now we should focus on your mission for Lady Aribeth.
I believe the discovery of the leaven bread recipe could have far reaching benefits, and I would like to someday be able to bring a copy back to my home of Lantan.
But I know your mission is more important, <FirstName>. I will not let my scientific curiosity get in the way of your work.
Never fear, <FirstName>. My work with you will take precedence over my search for the leaven bread recipe.
Thank you, <FirstName>. But for now we must return to the task at hand. Aribeth is counting on you.
You do? This... this is wonderful! Yes, this is exactly what I need!
I have no gold or treasure to reward you, but there is one thing I can offer. A small token, perhaps, but it is all I have.
Before I left Lantan I was given this ring by my master, Prophyro. He said it embodies the essence of discovery and the quest for knowledge.
Because you have helped me in discovering the miracle of this leaven bread, I feel you have earned your right to wear this ring.
There is power in this ring, <FirstName>.
The ring comes from the island of Lantan, island of discovery and invention. It has the power to grant insight to its wearer.
I regret there is nothing else I can give you, <FirstName>, but once more I thank you for what you have done.
But we should return our attention to greater matters now and resume your mission. Aribeth is counting on you.
I told you earlier I came to Neverwinter to study the Wailing Death, <FirstName>. But there was another reason I came, as well. Given all that has happened, it seems rather unimportant now.
But you did ask me, so I must conclude you are interested in my motivations. I have come to Neverwinter in search of bread.
I know how foolish this sounds, but I had heard tales of a special type of bread found only here in Neverwinter - leaven bread, they call it.

It is said the loaf stays fresh for months and that it will never go stale or moldy. I was hoping that when I came to Neverwinter I could find someone to teach me the secret of making this wondrous leaven bread.

If we could determine the agents that keep the bread from spoiling I think the principles could be applied to any number of other uses! With a little research this discovery could mean so much more than simple bread.
I looked for some time when I first arrived in the city but it seems the secret is known only to a few master bakers, and unfortunately they have all been claimed by the plague.
I suppose someone still has a copy of the recipe somewhere, but the more I witnessed the death and suffering in this place the less important discovering the leaven bread became.
You seem quite interested in my time as an apprentice under Prophyro, <FirstName>. I suppose we can afford a few minutes for me to recount those days for you.

Prophyro instilled in me the basic principles of magic and the underlying laws governing the arcane. His knowledge and wisdom were an inspiration to me, though his organizational skills were somewhat lacking.
I would constantly stumble across magic items carelessly strewn about the tower. Potions and elixirs from half finished experiments would be left sitting out on the kitchen table.
Ancient scrolls he had been copying would be stuffed under the cusions of his chairs, wands would turn up in closets and drawers.
And he never, ever locked his laboratory despite the countless powerful magic items and dangerous experiments he often dabbled in.
What? You don't think I was foolish enough to begin tampering with things beyond the scope of my understanding, do you?
I came to Prophyro so he could teach me. It wouldn't be logical for me to begin experimenting on my own. What would have been the point of studying under him if I was going to do that?
I admit, seeing all those potions and wands and scrolls just lying around was difficult. And I must confess that eventually I did give in to the temptation.

I just snapped. I couldn't take it anymore, and I did something rash and completely out of character. I waited until my Master left on an extended trip and then I... I cleaned up Prophyro's laboratory!

I organized the scrolls and potions and wands. I built shelves to store the magical components of his research and I made a catalog card system so he could cross reference all of his tests and results.
Items that were particularly powerful or unstable I locked safely away in a magically reinforced chest with a key that I presented to Prophyro on his return.

What can I say, <FirstName>. I was young and foolish. Prophyro's own reaction was similar to yours - he couldn't believe what I had done, although he did continue to use the filing system I had set up for him.
Of course I was curious, <FirstName>, but my hunger for experimentation was tempered by reason. Imagine the damage I could have done if I had dared experiment on my own.
I was an apprentice, so the sensible course of action was for me to follow the lead of my master. Any other course of action would have been... illogical.
I admit my actions may seem overly... cautious. But that is the way of my people. Curiosity is tempered with careful analysis.
However, ever since I left Lantan I find I am growing more bold in my quest for discovery. After all, I did come to a plague infested city in order to chronicle a new disease... among other things.
I'm sorry, <FirstName>, I should not have said anything about this to you. It is really a trivial matter and you have far more important things on your mind.
You don't have to worry about that, <FirstName>. I'm anxious to find the source of this foul plague, and I won't let my other interests get in the way.
You are a sorcerer just as I am, <FirstName>. Logically I would assume our experiences in our early training were quite similar.
Your request is completely logical, <FirstName>, and I will be happy to answer your inquiries. However, as you might expect I have some questions of my own.
Why are you here, <FirstName>? What events are the underlying basis of your service to Aribeth and the city of Neverwinter?
I should have guessed, <FirstName>. The allure of gold is a common connection among many who undertake missions such as yours. My own motivations in coming here were somewhat different.
I should have guessed, <FirstName>. The allure of fame is a common connection among many who undertake missions such as yours. My own motivations were somewhat different.

When I heard about the plague I was flush with the thrill of scientific discovery. I thought that if I applied the principles of observation and experimentation I could discover a cure for the plague.
It was only after I arrived that I realized how wrong my preconceived notions were. I suppose the need to learn this lesson was one of the reasons my mentor insisted on sending me out from Lantan.
I am a sorcerer, I have the ability to unleash powerful and dangerous forces. I would have been foolish to undertake this career path without seeking the guidance of one more experienced than I.
However, sorcerers and wizards are not common in Lantan. We prefer to find a scientific solution to problems whenever possible, rather than relying on magic.
At last I managed to locate another who could train me in the arcane arts - a human sorcerer named Prophyro who lived in a secluded tower on the far side of the island.
I admit that when I first arrived at Prophyro's tower I did not receive a warm welcome. Or rather to be more accurate, I should say I received an overly warm welcome.

Just as I reached Prophyro's tower a large lizard popped out from behind a nearby bush. It was somewhat alarming. However, when the creature opened its jaws and belched forth a jet of flame I became absolutely terrified.

I fled back the way I had come, the fire drake's blasts of flame licking at my heels the entire way. As soon as I passed beyond the boundaries of Prophyro's land, the creature turned and disappeared back into the bushes.

Easier said than done, I'm afraid. I am not skilled with weapons and at the time my magic was of such low level as to be virtually useless. Plus, killing the pet of the man I wanted to study under was hardly a good first impression.

Once I had regained my wits, I realized the fire drake served a dual purpose: it was a guardian for Prophyro's estate, but it also provided a challenge for any would-be apprentices who might wish to approach him.

If I could find a way to best the creature I was certain Prophyro would see my potential and accept me as an apprentice. The problem was how to get past the creature when my magic was barely capable of igniting a candle.
I had to rely on my mind to solve the problem, so I began to analyze the facts as I knew them. And I realized the creature was nothing more than an illusion.

I simply looked at the evidence. Fire drakes are not indigenous to my island and the climate is hardly suitable for one to survive. Plus, I had noticed no burnt patches of grass or scorched bushes on the grounds.
And the flames I felt licking at my heels had done no damage to my shoes and clothing. Armed with undeniable proof of the illusion I marched up to the tower once again.

When the lizard appeared I simply ignored it. It charged straight at me, fire and smoke spewing from its jaws. But I held my ground and a split second before the beast bowled me over it disappeared in a shower of light.

The door to the tower swung open. I stepped in to see an old man in robes. He smiled at me and said, "Well done, Boddyknock Glinckle. You have proven yourself worthy of being my student. I am Prophyro."
You are right, of course. My tale can wait, we have more pressing matters to attend to right now.
I'm sorry, <FirstName>, but this isn't the most reasonable time to discuss this, is it? After all, Neverwinter is in great peril.
Compassion is an admirable trait, <FirstName>, though I must confess my own motivations when I came here were quite different.
I think we need to change your tactics.
I think we need to part ways now, Grimgnaw.
We need to change the distance you stay away from me.
Stay close.
Medium distance.
Far distance.
Nevermind.
Could we change how quickly you decide to heal me.
Heal me if I become somewhat injured (below 75% of total hit points).
Heal me if I become wounded (below 50% of total hit points).
Heal me if I become seriously wounded (below 25% of total hit points).
Could you not search all the time?
Could you please search when we move around?
Could you use more stealth when we travel?
Could you stop being so stealthy all the time?
If I fail to open a locked door or chest please come to my aid.
If I fail to open a locked door or chest do not assist me.
I don't want to change anything else right now.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> How about 100 and the promise of lots and lots of killing?
We need change way you do stuff.
Me no want you here no more, Grimgnaw. You go now.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> What if me give 100 but me promise we do lots and lots of killing?
I could use a monk at my side. Here's your 150 gold. Welcome aboard, Grimgnaw.
Here be you 150 gold. Now you be me slave.
I'll be going now.
Me go now.
125? Deal.
I could use a monk by my side. Here's your 200 gold. Welcome aboard, Grimgnaw.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> How about 150 and the promise of lots and lots of killing?
Here be 200 gold. Now you be me slave.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> What if me give 150 but me promise we do lots and lots of killing?
I could use a good fighter. Here's your 250 gold. Welcome aboard, Grimgnaw.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> How about 200 and the promise of lots and lots of killing?
Here be 250 gold. Now you be me slave.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> What if me give 200 but me promise we do lots and lots of killing?
175? Deal.
225? Deal.
You change how far away you stay.
You need change how you heal me.
You not search all time no more.
You search all time when we move.
You stop sneaking so quiet now.
You start sneak quiet now.
If me fail on locked door or chest you help me.
If me fail on locked door or chest you not help me.
Me not want change anything else now.
You heal if me sort of hurt (below 75% of total hit points).
You heal if me wounded (below 50% of total hit points).
You heal if me hurt real bad (below 25% of total hit points).
I don't have that kind of gold to spend on a henchman.
Me not got that much gold for spend on you.
Who are you? How do you know about the Academy?
I don't feel like talking right now. Goodbye.
What's in the Beggar's Nest?
I'm looking for a good mercenary to help me in my mission.
Why haven't you investigated the Beggar's Nest yourself?
Actually, I'm looking for some hired help to assist me on my mission.
I'll be going now.
I want to ask you some questions about Neverwinter.
Well, I wasn't acting alone. Aribeth and the other city guard did as much as I.
Yes, that would be me.
Who you be? How you know 'bout the Academy?
Me not wanna talk. Goodbye.
What be in the Beggar's Nest?
Me looking for mercenary to help on mission.
Why you not go check out Beggar Nest youself?
Me looking for help in me mission.
Me go now.
Me want to ask questions 'bout Neverwinter.
Me have lots of help! Aribeth and... Aribeth... and... nevermind.
Me greatest one there is! Me save city!
So you're working for Aribeth?
Goodbye.
You work for Aribeth? Me work for Aribeth too!
(Sluuurp) Oops, me sorry. So how you get hired by Aribeth?
If you're so interested in vengeance, why are you standing around here?
If you want kill cult, why you stand around here?
I guess I could use a homicidal monk at my side. You're in.
Sorry, but I'm not interested. Goodbye.
Me need psycho monk to help in fights. You in.
Sorry, me not interested.
Have you heard any rumors about the cult since you've come here?
You hear any stuff about cult? Me looking for clues.
Charwood?
So are you going to look into it some more?
So why are you standing around here? Shouldn't you be out scouring the north for this cult?
You gonna try to find out more stuff about the cult and Charwood?
Why you stand around here? You supposed to be looking for cult.
I'd like you to level up. You'd be more useful to me with a little training.
Me want you to level up. You be better with training.
I just want to talk for a while.
Me just wanna talk.
If you're going to be my henchman, I'd like to know more about you.
I want you to continue your story from before.
Nevermind.
Me wanna know you better. Me think that important.
Me want you continue you story from before.
I have seen too much death and suffering from the plague to stand idly by.
I seek to forge a legend that will last for ever.
Aribeth has promised me gold and riches if I can help her in this.
Tell me more about the Order of the Long Death, Grimgnaw.
That's all well and good, but just remember that until your death comes you're serving me.
Me want know more 'bout you Order of Long Death.
That all nice, but you not forget that until you be dead you be serving me!
I have a ring here with a falcon on it. Is this the ring?
If I find it I'll let you know.
Me found ring with bird on it. Maybe this be ring you look for.
If me find it me let you know.
If we're going to be traveling together I'd like to know a little more about you.
I'd like you to continue your story from before, Grimgnaw.
If we be travel together, me want know more 'bout you.
Me want you keep talking 'bout story you start before.
I wouldn't mind knowing your thoughts on Aribeth's betrayal. How do you feel about it?
I want you to continue with what you were telling me before.
Me want to know what you think about Aribeth betraying everyone. How you feel 'bout that?
Me want you to continue you story from before.
Tell me more about your Order, Grimgnaw.
What kind of enemies are you talking about?
You're talking about the undead, right? Liches and zombies and the like.
I have a mummified hand here. Will this do.
Don't worry, I'm sure we'll find the components you're looking for.
Just don't let this get in the way of your other duties.
Me got mummy hand here. This be what you need?
You not worry. We find stuff you need for you ritual.
Accepting death is one thing. Having your lover hung right in front of you is something else.
I have a dagger here with a skeletal hand on it. Is this one of the blessed weapons?
Then if the Silent Lord wills it, we'll find one of the sacred weapons.
Me got knife here with bony hand on it. Maybe this be what you look for.
You not worry Grimgnaw. Me keep killing stuff 'till you find weapon.
You again? Are you following me like some kind of pathetic lost puppy?
What are you doing here, Grimgnaw?
So you were conscripted into service by Aribeth?
How much would it cost to hire your services?
Goodbye.
I could use a monk by my side.
Do you have any information on the cult behind the Wailing Death?
I don't need anything right now.
I did my duty.
I know, I'm great. What can I say?
Me do duty.
Me am so great! Me am so great!
So you're working for Aarin Gend?
You work for Aarin Gend? Me work for Aarin too!
Goodbye.
Have you heard any rumors as to where the Words could be?
Why are you standing around here? Shouldn't you be looking for these Words?
You heard any rumors about where Words be? Me want to find them.
Why you stand here? You should look for Words.
I could use a homicidal monk. Come on.
Sorry, I'm not interested.
Me could use psycho monk. Come on.
Me not like you.
It is good to see you again, Grimgnaw.
I'm getting sick of seeing your ugly mug every time I turn around!
Do you know anything about the Words of Power, Grimgnaw.
We should join up again, Grimgnaw.
Sorry but I don't need any help right now.
Yes.
No, not now.
Yes.
No.
What's a monk of the Long Death order doing in Neverwinter?
What kind of skills does a monk of the Order of the Long Death possess?
Why monk of Long Death order be here in Neverwinter?
What kind of skill you be say you got?
You seem a little bit creepy, Grimgnaw.
You be creepy, dwarf.
Me see lots people die. Me not like it. Me want help them.
If me save Neverwinter then me be big hero.
Me get lots gold if me help Neverwinter!
Mithral Hall? Is that where you come from originally?
Mithral Hall? Me not know you come from there.
Shunned? What do you mean?
We don't have time for this now. We need to stay focused on our mission.
Shun? What you mean?
We not got time for this. We need get back to what our mission be.
How did you end up joining the Order of the Long Death?
How you end up in Order of Long Death?
Who?
And you followed her here?
I'll help you find and kill Alaganda - or at least help you find her ring.
She's probably dead already, and the ring could be anywhere in the city. You'll never find it.
Me help you kill girly. Or if she dead already, me help you find ring.
She probably dead already. This city be big place - you never gonna find ring here.
As long as you don't let your search interfere with your service to me!
You not let you search get in way of stuff you do for me!
Do you have any advice or suggestions you can give me about my mission?
You got any hint or tip you give me 'bout this mission?
Why are you so interested in the Beggar's Nest?
Why you want see Beggar Nest?
I think that's enough talking for now.
Me not want talk no more.
Thank you, Grimgnaw.
That's it? A cheap amulet?
What can you tell me about the Dragon Mountains?
You know stuff 'bout Dragon Mountains?
What you be doing here, Grimgnaw?
You again? Is you following me like some stupid puppy?
Aribeth force you to come serve here?
How much it cost for you work for me again?
You know stuff 'bout that cult that spread plague?
Me need monk like you for help me.
Me not need nothing right now.
Charwood?
You used to live 'round here?
Me glad for see you again, Grimgnaw.
Me sick of you! Everywhere me go you ugly face be there!
You know stuff 'bout Words of Power?
We should be join up again, dwarf.
Sorry, me not need no help right now.
You used to live in this region?
Tell me more about you Order, dwarf.
What enemies you be talking about?
What happened?
I thought you liked killing and death.
What was so scary about zombies and skeletons? They aren't so tough.
Me thought yo like killing and death.
What be so scary 'bout zombie and skeleton. They not so tough.
I didn't realize you were so squeamish.
You mean you had to kill some of your own companions?
You had to kill you own friends?
What about the lich?
I'm sorry for what happened to the other monks of your Order, Grimgnaw.

What you need me do?

What kind of component is you looking for?
You better not let you search get in way of work for me!
The reward you offer is greater than you know, Grimgnaw.
Great. That and a couple coppers will get me a mug of warm ale.
You not need give me reward. You thanks be reward enough.
What good that do me? Me not buy stuff with thanks and friendship!
So you disapprove of what she has done?
It be one thing for accept death. It be another to watch you lover be hanging from rope.
So you not think it right what she done?

How wheel work?

Sound like you Order kills everyone who want to join. That not too smart.

Me not help you with nothin' 'til me find Power Words.
This quest better not interfere with your duty to me!
You quest better not get in way of stuff you do for me!

Me thank you for this.
