What are you going to do now, Grimgnaw?
What you do now, Grimgnaw?
Wait? Wait for what?
Wait? Why for you got to wait?
You're a sick and evil man, Grimgnaw. Too evil for my taste.
You be sick and evil, dwarf. Me not like you.
I just think it's time we parted ways.
Me just think it time we go apart.
I've changed my mind. Stick with me and we'll leave a trail of bodies across the land!
Me change mind. You stay and we leave trail of bodies all over this land!
Did you ever go there youself?
Did you ever investigate the Beggar's Nest on your own?
So the Silent Lord is the god your Order worships?
So Silent Lord be God you order worship?
Your Order sounds pretty evil, Grimgnaw.
You Order sound like it be real bad evil.
But they wouldn't accept you, would they?
You said before they shunned you. What happened?
Them other dwarves not want you around, do they?
You said them others shun you. What happen?
Did they reject you because you were part of the Long Death Order?
Did them send you away 'cause you be part of Long Death Order?
Can't say I've had the pleasure.
That's horrible!
I've seen my share of killing, if that's what you mean.
That be horrible!
Me not ever had that pleasure.
Me seen lots of killing, if that what you mean.
No kidding - you're a freak, Grimgnaw!
They were weak, Grimgnaw. They couldn't dare to face death like you.
You be big weirdo freak, dwarf!
Them just weak. Them scared of death. They not strong like you, Grimgnaw.
What do you mean by that?
What you mean?
You can tell me, Grimgnaw. Maybe it's something I can help you with.
Fine - just don't let it distract you from the job at hand!
It okay, dwarf. You can tell me you secret and maybe me can help you.
Okay, but you not let you problem get in way of you work for me!
You follow here here?
Proof? What kind of proof?
Me not gonna just stand by and watch you kill innocent woman!
I'm not going to just stand by and watch you kill an innocent woman!
This isn't right. I must part ways with you now, Grimgnaw.
Actually, I don't have a problem with killing this woman.
This not be right. Me not want stay with you no more.
It okay. You stay. Me not care if you kill girly.
Tell me about Charwood.
You tell 'bout Charwood.
Have you ever been to Charwood?
You ever be to Charwood?
Is your Order evil, Grimgnaw?
Is you Order be evil, dwarf?
You worship death - it's no wonder you have enemies!
You be death cult! It no wonder you have enemies!
What do you mean?
What you mean?
You're a sick man, Grimgnaw.
You one sick man, dwarf.
I don't think I want to get involved with this.
Me not want get mixed up in this.
How do we get to the Dragon Mountains?
How we get at Dragon Mountain?
You used for live 'round here?
You used to live in this region?
That's a horrible thing to say!
You're a bloodthirsty freak, Grimgnaw. I like it!
That bad thing to say!
You sicko freak, dwarf! Me like it!
I could never believe these things to be beautiful, Grimgnaw. You're an evil, evil man!
Me not ever think this stuff be beautiful, Grimgnaw. You be sick little man!
I kill when I have to, Grimgnaw, but I doubt I'll ever see anything beautiful in it.
Me kill when me have to. Me not ever see nothing beautiful in it.
Death, killing, pain, torture - I already love those things, Grimgnaw. Maybe I could join your Order?
Me already like killing and torture and stuff. Maybe me could join you Order?
I'd never want to hear about that stuff anyway!
Me not never want hear 'bout tha anyway!
So enlighten me. Tell me about your Order's rituals.
You teach me. Tell me 'bout you rituals and stuff.
What kind of monster are you, Grimgnaw? You deserve death!
You be monster, Grimgnaw! You deserve death!
Fine. Go on.
But me thought you already be member of you Order!
What task?
Sounds simple.
Why would they bless a weapon just so someone else can use it to kill them?
Why them bless weapon just so some guy can use it for kill them?
So you want me to find this weapon for you?
You want me for find weapon for you?
So wouldn't my help be a violation of your Order's beliefs?
But if me help you that not be against the rules?
How will I recognize one of these blessed weapons?
How me know when me find blessed weapon?
Yet there are many whom death will follow in this city - many who are willing to pay for my services. My fee to join your cause is 150 gold pieces.

I will obey your every command, for your decisions herald the spread of death and bloodshed.
At what distance do you want me to stay?
Of course. How soon would you like me to heal you?

I know you. You were at the Academy during the slaughter of the students. You were there when the assassins came.
I foresee a future of brutal and savage slaughter at your side, <FirstName>. My Order will be pleased.
Yet there are many whom death will follow in this city - many who are willing to pay for my services. My fee to join your cause is 200 gold pieces.

We part now, but you are destined to swim in an ocean of blood. Our fates are intertwined, and I shall wait here for your inevitable return so we may once more join together to perform the will of the Silent Lord.
I will obey your every command, for your decisions herald the spread of death and bloodshed.
How far away do you want me to stay?
Very well, I shall stay reasonably close to you whenever possible.
Very well, I shall stay a medium distance away from you whenever possible.
Very well, I shall stay a reasonably far distance away from you whenever possible.
Is there anything else?
Was there anything else?
I shall do as you have asked.
Very well, I will no longer search while we are moving.
Very well, I will search whenever we are moving.
Very well, I will travel in stealth mode from now on.
Very well, I will no longer travel in stealth mode.
Very well, I will open any locked door or chest that you fail to open.
Very well, I will no longer attempt to open locked doors or chests.
Then I am afraid we cannot work together, though I have no doubt you will be an instrument of destruction and an agent of Death even without me at your side.
You are back, <FirstName>. The blood from those slaughtered at the Academy may be washed away, but I still recognize the mark of Death upon you.
I know you. You are <FullName>, the one who emerged from the corpse clogged streets of Neverwinter to save the city from the horrors of the Wailing Death.
We meet again, <FirstName>. It is I, Grimgnaw of the Order of the Long Death. Surely you must remember me.
We meet again, <FirstName>. I taste a storm of slaughter on the air; I'm not surprised to find you here at the center of the whirlwind.
I know you, <FullName>. I know of your deeds. I know how many thousands of people hail you as a hero - and I know how many more have died screaming at your feet.
The fires of war are burning on horizon, <FirstName>. Why am I not surprised to see you here to forge your blood drenched legacy in the furnace of slaughter?
You have returned, <FirstName>. Are you looking to join with a servant of the Long Death?
I have been waiting for you - I suspected you would return. Do you need me to join with you once more?
I serve another master now. I have nothing more to say to you.
To be torn from the embrace of the Silent Lord is... unsettling. Yet my time to bow down before him for all eternity is not yet here. Do you need me to join you once more, <FirstName>?
A storm of blood swirls around you, anguish and death will follow in your wake... just as it did at the Academy.
IGNORE THIS STARTING CONDITION. THIS IS USED AS A TRASH FOR UNWANTED LINKS. DO NOT DELETE THESE LINKS.
You are welcome to return should you have need of my skills, <FirstName>. If not, we shall meet again at our final end, when the Silent Lord claims us all.
Tell me - as you stood amidst the blood-soaked corpses of your fellow students, did you gaze upon the face of Death? Did you look into His cold eyes and feel His icy touch upon your soul?
So far I have uncovered no answers on my own that might help end this epidemic, though I am eager to search the Beggar's Nest.
The monks of the Long Death rarely join with those outside our order, but I sense the mark of my master is upon you.
I have heard rumors that in that blighted district zombies walk the streets. Few things are so reviled by my order as the abomination of the undead.
Alone I am not likely to survive the dangers of the district, and throwing my life away is a foolish way to serve the Silent Lord. My death will come in its appointed time.
So far I have uncovered no answers on my own that might help end this epidemic, though I am eager to search the Beggar's Nest.
Others may have been involved, but I know the truth of things. I see the mark of the Silent Lord upon you.
I have known about you ever since the massacre at the Academy, <FirstName>. A beautiful maelstrom of brutal slaughter swirls around you.
Yes, we have already established that you work for Aribeth. Perhaps you could wipe the drool from your chin. It truly is repulsive.
Return to me if you require an ally in your mission. Together we can help sow the seeds of destruction throughout the land and reap a harvest of agony and death.
I am eager to punish those who unleashed the Wailing Death upon Neverwinter. Thousands were taken by the disease, their essence stolen from the grasp of true Death.
That was why I answered Lord Nasher's desperate call for mercenaries to come to Port Llast. He is also anxious to root out those behind the Wailing Death.
Running helter skelter on my own would do little to locate the cult, and even less to further the cause of Death, whom I serve.
Your reputation is well known, <FirstName>. I have heard many tales of the slaughter you rain down upon those who dare oppose you.
The mark of Death is upon you. If we join together we shall unleash a storm of devastation to ravage the North and feed the eternal hunger of the Silent Lord.
Their location is well hidden. However, I would not be surprised to learn they are connected with the village of Charwood.
The town has isolated themselves from the rest of the world, far to the South of Port Llast. Few outside my Order even remember such a place exists.
It would not surprisie me to discover links to the cult behind the Wailing Death in that unnatural place.
Of course I will bow to your lead, <FirstName>. You are the herald of the Silent Lord, a ravager of destruction; pain and death follow in your wake.
I will follow you and perform to the best of my abilities, according to the orders you have given me. Any time you wish to issue new orders you have only to speak to me again.
My skills have improved somewhat. Give me a few seconds to rest and I shall be ready to show you my new skills.
Conversation is one way to pass the time until the Silent Lord comes to claim us. What do you wish to speak about.
Then we should continue with your mission. The Silent Lord is hungry for us to deliver more souls to His gaping maw.
I would ask, <FirstName>, that you tell me about yourself first. I am eager to know what type of <man/woman> I have allied myself with.
Why do you serve this plague ravaged city? What possesses you to venture out into the streets amidst the bloated, swollen corpses and the burning funeral pyres?
What the plague brings upon the people of this city cannot truly be called death; there is no final release for the victims of this illness into the waiting grasp of the Silent Lord.
The name of a hero lives on long after the hero has passed from this world. But do not fool yourself, <FirstName>. Your legend may live forever, but you will not.
Material wealth has its uses, but your gold and gems will mean nothing when the Silent Lord comes to claim you.
True Death - the ultimate end of existence - is the one perfect absolute in a flawed world of uncertainty. The Order of the Long Death understands this.
We bring pain, torment and anguish to the denizens of this world to prepare them for the release of death. We spread devastation; we seek to tear down, to obliterate and to destroy.
My Order does not bow before any god; we worship Death itself, in all its incarnations. Gods are transient - even a god may die: Bhaal, Bane, Cyric.
We all serve Death in one way or another, <FirstName>. It was only after I left Mithral Hall to join the Order that I truly came to understand this.
Very well, <FirstName>. I have been reluctant to speak of my time at Mithral Hall, but you will not let the matter rest.
I told you earlier this was a matter for those of my Order, <FirstName>. But you have proven yourself to be an agent of the Silent Lord - death follows you wherever you go.
I will not rest until I find the ring that proves Alaganda has been taken by the Silent Lord, though I know my chances of success are... few.
This is not the time to speak of this, <FirstName>. Let us return to our mission - the Silent Lord's hunger will not be sated by mere words.
I am a monk of the Order of the Long Death, <FirstName>. I am defined by the customs, tenets and beliefs of my Order. Simply put, I worship Death.
We worship the very essence of Silent Lord, and we honor the tools that prepare us all for our inevitable, inescapable end: pain, suffering, torment, agony.
Our embrace of the Silent Lord has brought us into conflict with many who do not understand the beauty of death.
Many fear their mortal end; for most we will simply use pain, anguish, torture and suffering to release them from this fear. We will prepare them for the cold embrace of the Silent Lord.
But there are some who go to extremes to avoid their fate. They use foul rituals and dark necromancy to deny the Silent Lord that which is his due.
Earlier I mentioned my Order's hatred of the abomination that is undeath, <FirstName> - and I hinted at my own experience in battling such evil.
My Order has many secrets, <FirstName>. Secrets we do not reveal to those outside our monastery. Yet you have proven yourself a friend of the Long Death before.
I will not abandon the search for the cultists behind the plague; I have pledged to aid you in destroying those who released the foul taint of the Wailing Death.
This is not the time to speak of such things, <FirstName>. We must focus on rooting out the cult responsible for the Wailing Death. Perhaps we can speak of this later... when the time is right.

I have mixed feelings about the paladin's actions. They say she was driven to her betrayal by the execution of her lover - she could not accept his death and it drove her mad with grief and a desire for revenge.
Very well, <FirstName>. The beauty of death is not easily understood, but if you are willing I will tell you of some of the rituals I endured when I joined the Long Death.
I have been waiting for guidance from the Silent Lord before I discussed this matter with you, <FirstName>. But I realize now what a fool I was.
Do not fear, <FirstName>. As long as you seek the Words of Power I shall serve you. And in serving you I serve the will of the Silent Lord.
Perhaps later I will speak more of this, but now is not the time. You are not yet ready. Let us return to our mission, for in doing so we will surely spread death throughout the North.
You have proved yourself a true servant of the Silent Lord, <FirstName>. Take this amulet; all who join the Long Death are given a similar talisman.
Let me see... yes, this may work. The taint of undeath has not yet contaminated the dessicated flesh of this limb.
Once more you have proved yourself an agent of my Master, <FirstName>. I bestow upon you this talisman, a gift normally reserved only for those of my Order.

The Silent Lord has many tools to reap his harvest, Alaganda may have succumbed to the plague or other... misfortune. But I will search the city until I either kill her or find the ring that proves she is already dead.
But even though we were ultimately victorious, the cost was terrible. The horror of the battle haunts me still - as does the fate of my fallen brothers and sisters from the Order.
That I am not yet ready to share with you, <FirstName>, for I have not yet completed it.
The sacred weapons are all emblazoned with the symbol of my Order - the outstretched hand of the Silent Lord reaching to claim us all.
Ultimately I follow no one but the Silent Lord, <FirstName>. I have been drawn here in the service of my master, Death.
When we parted ways, <FirstName>, I meant to return to my Order. But I bow to the Silent Lord and I discovered I could best serve his will by staying in Neverwinter for the time being.
I am eager to find and slaughter those who unleashed the Wailing Death upon Neverwinter. Thousands were taken by the disease, their essence stolen from the grasp of true Death.
When Aribeth recruited the mercenaries we were all paid in advance for our services - well paid. Lord Nasher is sparing no expense in tracking down these cultists.
Return to me if you require an ally in your mission. Together we can help sow the seeds of destruction throughout the land and reap a harvest of agony and death.
Then together we shall sow death and destruction throughout the land in our quest to destroy those behind the Wailing Death.
Their location is well hidden. However, I would not be surprised to learn they are connected with the village of Charwood.
You have the mark of Death upon you, <FirstName> - the scent of slaughter is thick around you. I have no doubt brutal destruction follows closely in your wake.
Farewell, <FirstName>. If you seek a partner to revel in the bloodshed you must inevitably unleash, you can always find me here.
Yes, Aarin has hired dozens of mercenaries to aid him in this cause - though truth be told, I would have come to serve one side or the other in any case.
A war is brewing over these Words of Power. Slaughter and death will engulf the North, and as a monk of the Long Death I must be at the center of the carnage.
I have not heard anything of these Words, <FirstName>, though I once lived with my clan in the mountains to the North.
I am here seeking death and bloodshed, <FirstName>. I care nothing for these Words of Power. I only want to glory in the killing of others.
Together we shall bring a flood of death to drown the North, <FirstName>!
There are not many who claim it is good to see the members of my Order, <FirstName>. But you and I are of the same ilk - we do not shy from death and killing.
I serve the Silent Lord, I go where death is imminent. We are on the eve of war - that is why I have come, <FirstName>. I follow the scent of slaughter, not you.
When I heard Aarin Gend was recruiting mercenaries to his cause I knew you would come, <FirstName>, just as I did. Our fates appear once more to be bound together.
Aribeth's betrayal has stoked the fires of war, and I am eager to see the killing begin. If we are lucky this war will engulf the entire region.
Together we shall bring a flood of death to drown the North, <FirstName>.
As you wish, <FirstName>. No doubt you can spread havoc without my assistance. However, if you change your mind you can find me here.
I have not heard anything of these Words, <FirstName>, though I once lived with my clan in the mountains to the North.
Then together we shall rain blood and death down upon the world.
You are an agent of destruction and a messenger of death. Should you change your mind come back to me here and I will gladly join with you again.
Then together we shall rain blood and death down upon the world.
You are an agent of destruction and a messenger of death. Should you change your mind come back to me here and I will gladly join with you again.
I am a disciple of torment and a messenger of Death, the Silent Lord. I bring the absolution of pain and anguish to my enemies to prepare them for a brutal - and purifying - end.

There is a foul taint upon this city. Death - true, permanent death - is perfect in its absolute finality. Pain, suffering, anguish, torture: these are the tools that prepare us for my master's soothing embrace.
But this plague is unnatural, it's victims never pass to embrace of the Silent Lord. The Wailing Death is a blight upon the world that must be ended.
Many find the members of my Order unsettling, for we embrace Death in all its incarnations. Yet in times like these, my skills are in great demand.
There is little I can tell you about the city. I came expecting to find the pureness of suffering and the beautiful anguish of death.
It would be reasonable to imagine there is some connection between the undead and the unnatural end of those who succumb to the Wailing Death.
I spent several years at Mithral Hall in the service of Bruenor Battlehammer. Before I joined the Order of the Long Death.
You are right, <FirstName>. The hunger of the Silent Lord will not be fed by mere words.
When Bruenor Battlehammer reclaimed the throne at Mithral Hall not twenty years ago it kindled a fierce racial pride in all the dwarves of the North.
I was one of many who flocked to Bruenor's banner - one of many who came to battle the denizens of the Underdark and drive them from the mines beneath Mithral Hall.
You are a fellow dwarf, <FirstName>. Surely you can understand the desire to dwell among the legendary halls of our forefathers?
And even though the dwarves of Mithral Hall turned me away, I sense you will not do so.
I have not been completely honest with you about my reasons for coming to Neverwinter, <FirstName>. I came here in search of someone.
You are not one of the <brother/sister>s of the Long Death, <FirstName> - but you are a monk, as I am. You understand the duties and responsibilites owed to one's Order.
Her name is Alaganda; like me, she was a disciple studying to enter the Order of the Long Death. We often trained together in anticipation of our initiation.
I will not describe our initiation rituals to you, <FirstName>, but the Silent Lord claims many who undertake them. Only the few who survive, as I did, are welcomed into the Order of the Long Death.
But Alaganda could not bear to face her own mortality, and on the morning of her initiation she fled, breaking the vows she swore when she first joined the Order.
I did not follow her right away, the ravages of the ritual had left me broken and weak. But when I recovered my instructor came to me and told me what I must do.

Alaganda has denied the Silent Lord that which is rightfully his. For this she must die. And because I am the lone survivor of the most recent initiation, I am the one given the privilege of killing her.
Thank you, <FirstName>. But for now we must return to the task at hand. The Silent Lord's hunger must be fed with a constant supply of new victims.
My service to you will draw many into the cold grasp of the Silent Lord, <FirstName>. Death surrounds you. I would be a fool to let my other mission distract me from following in your bloody wake.
The essence of those claimed by the plague has been stolen from the terrible grasp of my master, Death. This sickness cheats the Silent Lord of what is rightfully his.
The location of the cult you seek is well hidden. However, I would not be surprised to learn they are connected with the village of Charwood.

Perhaps I can help you, for long ago my dwarf clan dwelt in the Dragon Mountains, though when Bruenor Battlehammer reclaimed Mithral Hall we left to join the others of our kind who flocked to his banner.
I have heard rumors that in that blighted district zombies walk the streets. Few things are so reviled by my order as the abomination of the undead.
It would be reasonable to imagine there is some connection between the undead and the unnatural end of those who succumb to the Wailing Death.
Yes, we should continue with your mission. The Silent Lord is eager for us to feed his endless hunger with more souls.
There is nothing else I can think of to tell you, <FirstName>.
Yes, this is Alaganda's ring! This is the proof I needed; now I know she has been taken by the Silent Lord. She was a fool to flee - there is nowhere we can run that Death cannot find us.
I have no gold or treasure to reward you, but there is one thing I can offer. A small token, perhaps, but it is all I have.
It will not save you from the Silent Lord when He finally chooses you, but it will grant you some protection from succumbing to those who would deliver you into his grasp before your appointed time.
Eventually I will return to my Order and report Alaganda's death to them. But this can wait until your mission here is done, <FirstName>.
The town has isolated itself from the rest of the world, far to the South of Port Llast. Few outside my Order even remember such a place exists.
I know the mountains were aptly named, for great wyrms could often be seen soaring over the moonlit skies at night.
There were many legends of the great hoards guarded by these winged serpents and the mighty artifacts that could be found within.
I do not specifically recall mention of the Words of Power, but I can only assume such a powerful item would likely be found in a dragon's lair.
Our instructions were simply to make ourselves available to whomever requires our assistance. So, in that spirit, is there anything I can do for you?
The town has isolated itself from the rest of the world, far to the South of Port Llast. Few outside my Order even remember such a place exists.
It would not surprisie me to discover links to the cult behind the Wailing Death in that unnatural place. Is there more I can do for you, <FirstName>?
I have been eagerly waiting for my chance to extract vengeance on the cult responsible for unleashing the plague on Neverwinter.
My name is Grimgnaw, a monk of the Order of the Long Death. Like you I serve the Silent Master, spreading pain and suffering and death throughout the North.
Long ago my dwarf clan dwelt in the Dragon Mountains, though when Bruenor Battlehammer reclaimed Mithral Hall we left to join the others of our kind who flocked to his banner.

At night great wyrms could often be seen soaring over the moonlit skies. There were many legends of the hoards these winged serpents guarded, and many rumors of the mighty artifacts that could be found within.
I do not specifically recall mention of the Words of Power, but I can only assume such a poweful item would likely be found in a dragon's lair.
Long ago my dwarf clan dwelt in the Dragon Mountains, though when Bruenor Battlehammer reclaimed Mithral Hall we left to join the others of our kind who flocked to his banner.

At night great wyrms could often be seen soaring over the moonlit skies. There were many legends of the hoards these winged serpents guarded, and many rumors of the mighty artifacts that could be found within.
I do not specifically recall mention of the Words of Power, but I can only assume such a poweful item would likely be found in a dragon's lair.
If you wish, <FirstName>, I will gladly join with you to seek out these Words of Power. I have no doubt our partnership would result in a scourge of death throughout the land.
Understand, I care nothing for the petty Gods who squabble over and lay claim to death's portfolio, for I serve Death itself, the Silent Lord who rules us all.
We of the Long Death train, study and serve our Masters. We strive to transcend the earthly world through mental discipline and philosophical understanding of Death.
The undead are a foul abomination, a denial of the natural order. We of the Long Death are in constant conflict with necromancers and their minions.
I have seen firsthand the horrors of a war with the undead, <FirstName>.
I am not eager to dredge up those memories, but if we are to stand together you deserve to hear the tale.
Shortly after I had come to join the Order of the Long Death one of my fellow monks returned to the monastery with ill news. He had discovered the lair of a powerful lich.
Our service to the Silent Lord demands that we destroy such an affront to death, so we marched forth to destroy the foul creature and end its unholy existence.
I myself never faced the lich in battle, but I was one of many assigned the task of destroying the lich's zombie and skeleton servants. Never have I felt such revulsion or terror during a battle.
There is beauty in death. The exquisite agony of a mangled soldier's screams well up in a glorious crescendo before ending on a single perfect note of eternal silence.
The writhing torment of a flailing body is transformed into the magnificent truth of a frozen corpse, forever stilled.
But when a corpse is not still; when the dead continue to shamble and stumble forward in a gross caricature of living flesh - where is Death's beauty then, <FirstName>?
My Order killed scores of zombies in the crypt that day, <FirstName>. Their bodies disintegrated beneath my blows in a shower of rotting flesh, yet they pressed inexorably forward.
But the true horror was yet to come. From the back of the tomb where the highest ranking monks of the Order battled the lich herself waves of dark necromancy spilled out over battlefield.
Several of my companions had fallen during the battle and as the foul spell touched their corpses they clambored to their feet, zombies under the will of the enemy we sought to destroy.
We do not fear death, <FirstName>, and had I been able to bring the Silent Lord's touch to my fallen comrades I would not have felt such revulsion at this memory.

But a zombie has no mind, it feels nothing. The pain that purifies and prepares us for death has no effect on such creatures; the understanding that comes during the moment of death is forever denied to such creatures.
I destroyed the animated lumps of flesh that were once my brothers and sisters in the Order, but I could not truly kill them. The undead can never be given such release.
The lich was destroyed, as were all its minions. We burned its lair, setting fire to the crypt so that the dark magic might be cleansed from a sacred place of death.
I thank you for your words, <FirstName>, though I doubt you truly understand. You bring death and destruction, but you do not understand it as we of the Long Death.
The true horror of what happened to my brothers and sisters is too terrible to comprehend; but I have vowed to free them from the torment of their undeath.
You couldn't possibly understand, <FirstName>. You are a harbinger of death, but you do not understand it as we of the Long Death.

You are a servant of the Silent Lord, <FirstName>; you bring death and pain to the world. Yet even so you are not a member of the Long Death. My Order has secrets I am not yet ready to share with you.
You aided me in finding the ring of Alaganda; I believe you would have helped me bring death to her had she still been alive when we found her.
Perhaps you can be of service to my Order once more, for without your aid I fear my brothers and sisters will never escape their terrible fate.
I should begin by explaining what happened after we burned the lich's lair. The corpses of our own, those who had risen against us, were brought back to the monastery of my Order.
There we sought to enact ancient rituals to release their essence from the curse that had bound them to their animated corpses. But the chains of undeath are not easily broken.
The components must come from the crypt of a powerful undead monster, but it must be something that has not yet been tainted by the creature's necromancy.
For example, we would require the preserved hand from an inanimate corpse within a mummy's crypt.
Only the power of such an item can release the essence of my brothers and sisters into the grasp of the Silent Lord.
This is but one aspect of my sevice to the Silent Lord, <FirstName>. The other is to follow your lead as you spread death and destruction across the land.
For the sake of my undead brothers and sisters, I can only hope so.
You will find that the blessing has enhanced the properties of the amulet I gave you when you found Alaganda's ring for me.
As a member of the Order of the Long Death her reaction to an inevitable event seems rather childish. The Silent Lord comes for us all; we might as well learn to accept it.
Much like the members of your own Order, a monk of the Long Death learns the skill to serve the will of the master.
Before an initiate can be accepted into the Order they must first learn to appreciate the beauty of death. We must walk the cemeteries and graveyards in search of this beauty.
We must live and dwell amongst the dead and dying. We must surround ourselves with that which others consider gruesome or macabre.
The next phase of our training is to understand the tools the Silent Lord uses to prepare us for death. Pain, suffering, sorrow, agony.
We participate in the torture of victims, we witness the sweet release they achieve when at last they succumb to death.
And then we subject ourselves to the same torments as our victims. We taste the pain and suffering as it burns away that part of us which clings to the mortal world.
Only through experiencing such pain can we understand how it prepares us to kneel at the altar of the Silent Lord. Pain is of this world, but it can release us to the next.
The Silent Lord claims many during this stage of the initiation. Those whom he has chosen to yet serve him in this world - those who survive - continue their training.
In the next stage of our initiation we must become true servants of the Silent Lord. We must murder three people - a rich old man, a poor young woman and a new born child.
By slaying a rich old man, a poor young woman and a new born babe we learn that all of us are subjects of the Silent Lord - male, female, young, old, rich, poor. Death has dominion over us all.
Next we must face the wheel, a simple test but one which delivers more initiates into the hands of the Silent Lord than any other.
The wheel teaches us that the Silent Lord chooses at His pleasure, not ours. We are subject to whims and chance, death is random.
The wheel is made of alternating white and black squares. If the pointer stops on a white square we move on to the final initiation. If it stops on a black square we are slain on the spot.
When I began the initiation there were six of us seeking to enter the Order. Two died on the torture racks, one was captured after murdering a wealthy, elderly merchant and hung.
That left three of us to face the wheel. I alone survived to face the final challenge.
I am a monk of the Long Death, <FirstName>. The final challenge is necessary only if I ever wish to enter the inner circle of my Order.
You are a tool of the Silent Lord. You enact His will upon this world, spreading death everywhere you go. The Silent Lord has brought us together for a reason!
I must assassinate one of the inner circle's members. Only by delivering one of their number into the Silent Lord's hands am I worthy to join them.
If I am meant to find one of the sacred weapons it will be in your service as you continue to carve out your blood steeped legend.
I could not have spoken it more truly myself, <FirstName>.
You are an instrument of the Silent Lord, <FirstName>. I will continue to serve you even as you continue to serve Death itself.
Yes - this is the mark of my Order. Wait... I fell a faint aura emanating from the blade. Yes - this is one of the weapons blessed by the inner circle!
The talisman has powerful magical properties bestowed by my Order, <FirstName>. Its power is not to be underestimated.
I suspect in practice we are similar to your own Order, though our beliefs and values may be somewhat different.
But during our mission I will not give up my search for the mummified hand of an inanimate corpse that can release my brethren from undeath.
Once again, <FirstName>, I thank you. Now let us return to the task at hand - those behind the Wailing Death must still be dealt with!
The dagger is only the beginning for me, <FirstName>. I now have the ability - and the right - to deliver one of the inner circle to the Silent Lord.
Yet the inner circle are among the most powerful of my order, and if I am to defeat one of them I must become a master of all I have learned.
Once I feel I am worthy I will challenge one of the inner circle to a battle to the death. But of course, all this must wait.
Your task here is not yet done, <FirstName>. You still seek the Words of Power, and in doing so you still bring death and destruction to your foes.
It has been an honor to serve you and I will not abandon you until your task is done.
Your words are cruel, but there is truth in them. However, I will not simply abandon my quest.
I am Grimgnaw, a monk of the Order of the Long Death. The grisly account of the Academy is no great secret, <FirstName>. Not to those who seek such things out.
In truth my skills are not so different from any soldier or hired blade, though I embrace the beauty and perfection of my enemy's death with a zeal others often lack.
Instead I discovered the plague is a foul abomination. It robs Death of its rightful claim and denies its victims the cold embrace of the Silent Lord.
You are an agent of death, <FirstName>, just as I am. We both serve the Silent Lord in our own fashion, though you refuse to acknowledge what you are.
Well spoken, <FirstName>. I tremble in anticipation of the carnage we shall unleash upon the Realms!
I do not know how we might stop the Wailing Death, though I am eager to search the Beggar's Nest for answers.
Alone I am not likely to survive the dangers of the district, and throwing my life away is a foolish way to serve the Silent Lord. My death will come in its appointed time.
But Death itself is always present. The Silent Lord is the name we give to the concept - the very essence - of Death.
There are some who call what we do evil, but my Order transcends morality. Good, evil - these things mean nothing, for eventually we all bow down to the Silent Lord.
The monks of my order bow down to Death, <FirstName>. We may swear allegiance to another, but only as it serves the will of the Silent Lord.
The monks of my order bow down to Death, <FirstName>. We may swear allegiance to another, but only as it serves the will of the Silent Lord.
We bring pain, torment and anguish to the denizens of this world to prepare them for the release of death. I have sworn to spread devastation and destruction in the name of the Silent Lord.
But there was no place for me among the clans at Mithral Hall; I was shunned and reviled by my own kind.
This was long before I joined the Order of the Long Death, and at first Mithral Hall welcomed me, for even then I did not fear death and I was eager to inflict it upon my enemies.

There were many among Bruenor's followers who shared my love of battle and the reckless fury with which I slaughtered my foes. But none of them appreciated the terrible beauty of what was all around us.

Have you ever heard the glorious chorus of screams of dying drow echoing in the chambers of a dwarven mine? Or paused in battle to taste the palpable specter of death descending on the field like a cool mist?

Have you ever stood over a dying comrade, drinking in his pain and fear as his life bleeds away, gazing into his eyes to glimpse the terrible understanding shining through in the final instant death claims him?
After the battles I would walk among the scattered corpses, fascinated by the... truth... of their deaths. The others found it disturbing, I knew, but I couldn't stop. The compulsion was too strong.

And as I wandered amidst the twisted, mangled bodies and gazed into the masks of agony forever frozen on their faces, I understood. Drow, duergar, dwarf - in death we are all the same. In death we are all... perfect.
I tried to share my revelations with my brothers-in-arms, but they could not understand. They only looked at me with horror and disgust.
That was what they said, as well, thought they were glad to have me at their side whenever the drow attacked.
I left Mithral Hall shortly after my revelation in search of... something. I found the Order of the Long Death.
I suppose I cannot blame my fellow dwarves for their reaction. The acceptance of Death is not easy. Even among my Order there are those who cannot face the Silent Lord when their time comes.
I'm sorry, <FirstName>, I should not have said anything about this to you. This is a matter that must be solved by those of my Order.
You don't have to worry about that, <FirstName>. I'm eager to end this foul plague that is taking what rightfully belongs to the Silent Lord.
If I am ever to advance further in the Order of the Long Death, I must bring back proof of Alaganda's death to my Masters.
Alaganda always wears a forged silver ring embossed with the crest of her family - a soaring falcon against a full moon.
After wearing it for so many years the ring will not fit over her finger, and she would never willingly remove the ring while she lives in any case.
Who among us is truly innocent, <FirstName>? Alaganda has participated in the rituals of the Long Death, she has slain many who you would call 'innocent'.
And she has broken her vows to my Order. The penalty for that is death. I will find her, <FirstName>, and I will kill her. If you cannot accept this we should part ways.
There is power in this amulet, <FirstName>.
The mark of Death is upon you, <FirstName>. As long as I stay by your side I know I serve the will of the Silent Lord.
That was why I answered Lord Nasher's desperate call for mercenaries to come to Port Llast. He is also anxious to root out those behind the Wailing Death.
The town is a strange place; there is a foul taint upon it that we of the Long Death can feel. None of the emissaries my Order has sent south to investigate Charwood has ever returned.
The town is a strange place; there is a foul taint upon it that we of the Long Death can feel, though we have not been able to determine what curse hangs over them.
It would not surprise me to discover links to the cult behind the Wailing Death in that unnatural place, though I can tell you little else about it.
I have never been there myself, though I know it lies far, far to the South of Port Llast. However, I know there must be great danger there.
My Order has sent many emissaries to investigate the region, but none have ever returned. There is some fell and dangerous power at work in Charwood, though what it is I cannot say.
I am Grimgnaw, a monk of the Order of the Long Death. No doubt you have come for the same reason as I: to join Aribeth in hunting and slaying the cult that was responsible for the Wailing Death.
The town is a strange place; there is a foul taint upon it that we of the Long Death can feel. None of the emissaries my Order has sent south to investigate Charwood has ever returned.
There are some who call us evil, for they fear the pain and death we spread. But we transcend morality. Death is not good or evil, it simply *is*. It is final, undeniable and perfect.
Our beliefs are difficult for most to accept, and the Order of the Long Death has many powerful enemies.
So be it. You are not bound by the tenets of my Order; you have sworn no allegiance to the Silent Lord.
I have pledged to accompany you in this mission, and I will continue to do so for the mark of my Master is upon you.

The ancient rituals require rare components and we had many casualties. A few we were able to save, but the others remain traped in undeath until we can find more of the necessary components for the ritual.
I thank you for this, <FirstName>, on behalf of the Order of the Long Death. I have no reward to give you, save the blessing of my Order.
The mountains are far to the west of Beorunna's Well, beyond the hills where the giants dwell.

In the days of my clan the giants were of little consequence; we often sent warriors to thin their numbers and chase them from their caves. Since my clan left, however, I have heard the giants have grown powerful and bold.
I have even heard talk of a hill giant king, though I cannot say if the rumors are true. We would have to investigate the region to be certain.
I would welcome the chance to join with you again and bathe in the storm of blood you will rain down upon the land.
The trail of corpses behind me cannot measure up to the thousands you have slain, but I am no stranger to death. Perhaps that is why Aarin Gend is so eager to have me on his side.
Together I am certain we can reap a mighty harvest for the Silent Lord, and hand him a bounty of souls to feed his ever hungry maw.

Your reputation is well known, <FirstName>. They say they cannot even count the thousands you have killed. As a servant of the Silent Lord I would be honored to join up with you, whatever your cause might be.
If you wish, <FirstName>, I will gladly join with you to seek out these Words of Power. I have no doubt our partnership would result in a scourge of death throughout the land.
Would she have felt better had her lover had his entrails removed by a hungry troll? Or had his limbs ripped from their sockets by an angry giant?

Or perhaps she would have been less angry had a slow acting poison drawn him into a sleep from which he would never awaken? Death is death, <FirstName>. My Order seeks to help the world understand this.
The motives for her actions seem foolish to me, but the results are pleasing. She has brought war to the North. Thousands will die painful, shrieking deaths beneath the blades she has unleashed.
The Silent Lord is eager to feast upon the table Aribeth has set for Him. And while Death gorges itself on the soldiers and civilians alike, I will be present to bear witness to my Master's gluttony.
You only say that because you do not comprehend the mysteries of the Silent Lord. If you understood the truth of Death you would not find my words so terrible.
You have a love of death and bloodshed that is rare outside our Order, <FirstName>. Yet even you cannot truly fathom the beauty of Death or the mysteries of the Silent Lord.

As a monk of the Long Death I was subjected to rituals and ceremonies that brought a true appreciation for that which others fear in their ignorance. Torture, pain, suffering and even death itself - these things are beautiful.
You bring destruction wherever you go, <FirstName>. Your motives may be good or evil, but that makes no difference. Death is forever by your side, the Silent Lord has placed his mark upon you.
Your enthusiasm is refreshing, <FirstName>. You revel in the Silent Lord's work, but you do not truly bow down to him. I sense you would still balk at your own death.
If I could share the experiences of my initiation you might begin to glimpse some small hint of what Death truly means - the only pure, absolute truth in an imperfect existence.
I imagine you would not be ready for such understanding anyway. You seem to have difficulty accepting that you are a harbinger of death.
No, <FirstName>, now is not the time. Eager as you are I am afraid you are not ready for the wisdom I would share.
Until you can accept that your fate is to deliver victims to the Silent Lord, I will not share the wisdom of my Order's initiations with you.
For many, this is the easiest part of our training. I myself was already enraptured with the corpses on the battlefields, I already understood the perfect truth of their deaths.
We all deserve death, <FirstName>. That is one of the fundamental truths of my Order. And in time we will all surely get what we deserve.
Our initiations are necessary for us to truly understand what Death is and what it represents. What we lack in numbers we make up for in conviction.
I want to ask you for aid in this, <FirstName>, but this challenge is sacred to the Order. Despite all you have done I am not yet certain you are ready to learn of our most hallowed secret.
I will not force you to aid me in this, <FirstName> - though I fear I will not succeed without your help. If you change your mind speak to me again.

Were I back at the monastery I could consult with the elders, but in their absence I can only wait and see if some sign is delivered to me. Only if I receive this sign will I be able to tell you of the final challenge, <FirstName>.
You are here to aid me in this challenge, <FirstName>. The very fact that you are here is proof the Silent Lord wants me to ask for your help in this task!
There is a... a catch, <FirstName>. It is forbidden for one of my Order to slay one of the inner circle unless we use a weapon blessed by the inner circle themselves.
You forget, <FirstName> - we do not fear Death. The custom exists to ensure that when one of the inner circle is slain it is by a monk who has been proved worthy of the honor.
When one of our Order joins the inner circle, they must bless a weapon that may be used to deliver them to the Silent Lord. They then take the weapon and secret it away in a place of great danger.
Finding one of these blessed weapons requires luck, skill and fate. In fact, we believe only the guiding hand of the Silent Lord will deliver a blessed weapon into the possession of one of our Order.
At first I feared enlisting your aid would be sacriligious. However, now I realize that you are a tool of the Silent Lord. You are here specifically to help me find one of the blessed weapons.
Together we can sow death and destruction throughout the North as we search for Aarin Gend's Words of Power.
Look at this severed hand, <FirstName>. See how the withered flesh has grown so tight and thin it exposes the delicate perfection of the bones beneath? Isn't it beautiful?
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> That seem high. Me give 200 only.
Here be 250 gold. Now me own you, Linu.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> That seems a little expensive. I'll give you 200.
225? Deal.
I could use a good healer. Here's your 250 gold. Welcome aboard, Linu.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> That seem high. Me give 150 only.
Here be 200 gold. Now me own you, Linu.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> That seems a little expensive. I'll give you 150.
175? Deal.
I could use a good healer. Here's your 200 gold. Welcome aboard, Linu.
Me go now.
Me not got that much gold for spend on you.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> That seem high. Me give 100 only.
Here be you 150 gold. Now me own you, Linu.
I'll be going now.
I don't have that kind of gold to spend on a henchman.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> That seems a little expensive. I'll give you 100.
125? Deal.
I need a good healer. Here's your 150 gold. Welcome aboard, Linu.
No.
Yes.
No, not now.
Yes.
Me be the greaterest, er... bestest! Yeah, me be the bestest!
Why they sing? Me just do duty.
Well, I should hope that they finally noticed a true hero.
There is nothing to sing about. I just did my duty.
Goodbye.
You work for Aarin Gend? Me work for Aarin too!
So you're working for Aarin Gend?
Why you stand here? You should look for Words.
You heard any rumors about where Words be? Me want to find them.
Why are you standing around here? Shouldn't you be looking for these Words?
Me not need you.
Me get hurt lots. Me could use you in me search for Power Words.
Sorry, I'm not interested.
I could use a skilled healer in this dangerous search for the Words.
Have you heard any rumors as to where the Words could be?
What about them?
Me get really tired of you cheery, happy face.
Me glad for see you again, Linu.
I'm getting tired of your silly, smiling face showing up wherever I go.
It is good to see you again, Linu La'neral.
Me not need no help right now.
I don't need any help right now.
Me want you near me 'gain, Linu.
I would love to have you travel with me again, Linu.
You know stuff 'bout Words of Power, Linu?
Do you know anything about the Words of Power, Linu?
What about them?
You silly, Linu. What happen to other ride?
Oh, Linu. What happened to the first ride?
What you do to it?
What did you do to it?
Broke? How it broke?
Broke? How did it break?
Me always get good laugh 'round you, Linu.
You never fail to surprise me, Linu.
Did them drivers kick you out?
Did the wagoneers throw you out?
There be song 'bout me? I be real hero now!
Bard sing about me? But me not do that much. Others help too.
Bards are singing about me? Excellent.
Goodbye.
Change you clothes? What happen?
Changing your clothes?
You get mad at her?
Did you get mad at her?
She soak you clothes?
She soaked your clothes?
Me see where this going.
I think I'm getting the picture.
That mess you up?
So that messed you up?
You got bad luck!
Disaster follows you, doesn't it?
You wreck clothes in brawl?
And you wrecked your outfit in the brawl?
You tell me you get dirty that way, please.
Please tell me that's how you got dirty.
You get dirty cleaning up.
So you got dirty cleaning up?
Me not feel safe 'round you. Me go away now.
I think I'll go somewhere else now. Maybe to a nice safe dragon lair.
Why you not say that first time me ask?
Why didn't you just tell me you slipped in a puddle from the start?
You work for Aribeth? Me work for Aribeth too!
Of course it be me. What you do to be hired to help?
So you're working for Aribeth?
If you want catch cult, why you stand around here?
If you want to bring them to justice, why are you waiting in here?
Sorry, me not interested.
Me need one who heal me wounds. You come.
Sorry, but I'm not interested. Goodbye.
I often am in need of a skilled healer. Join me.
You hear any stuff about cult? Me looking for clues.
Have you heard any rumors about the cult since you've come here?
Neverwinter Wood?
Why you be in here? You supposed to be finding cult.
You gonna go find more about the woods?
Why are you waiting around in here? Should you be investigating the problem?
Are you planning to travel there?
A bard? But I didn't do that much. Everyone working for Aribeth helped.
We say goodbye. Why you follow me here?
Me surprised me see you here, Linu.
I thought we parted ways. Why have you followed me?
Linu, what a pleasant surprise.
Me want you join me 'gain.
I want you to join me again.
Who you be 'gain?
Me want to ask questions.
Who are you again?
I want to ask you some questions.
Me not wanna talk to you. Goodbye.
I'm not in the mood to chat right now. Goodbye.
Who you be?
Who are you?
Go ahead.
No, me not. Why you ask?
No, I'm not. Why do you ask?
You seem to got problem with thief.
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> No-oooo. Me no be thief, honest.
That be all me, uh huh.
Me not like way you describe it, but yes, me a thief.
Sounds like you have something against thieves.
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> Uh, no.
That would pretty much sum me up, yes.
I don't like the rest of the description, but I am a thief, yes.
She not need them now!
It's not like she needed them anymore!
What kind of thief you run into?
If it look like worth gold, maybe.
My gods woman! What kind of thieves have you run into?
Well, if it looked like it was actually worth something, maybe.
No.
No, me want know what happen.
No, tell me what happened.
Okay.
Why you be in barracks, not with sick people?
Why are you here in the barracks, rather than helping the plague victims?
What happen next?
Then what happened?
Me not need you trippin' me all the time.
Just what I need, a cleric that's tripping and knocking things over every few minutes.
You really be so clumsy?
Are you really that clumsy?
That enough. Me not need more danger in life from you. Bye bye.
I've heard enough. You're dangerous to be around. Goodbye and better luck to you.
Why you be here then?
Then why are you here?
That be good of you.
That's good of you.
That sound like thing that happen to you often.
Sounds typical for your luck.
Them attack person who helps sick people?
They attacked you while you were helping plague victims?
Me looking for healer to help on mission.
I'm looking for a good healer to help me in my mission.
Me working for lady Aribeth. Can't tell you me mission. It secret.
Me work for lady Aribeth. Me looking for creatures. They are important. They cure plague.
I work for Lady Aribeth. My mission is confidential.
I work for Lady Aribeth. I must find several missing creatures that might be used to find a plague cure.
What other stuff you know 'bout Blacklake district?
Do you know anything else about the Blacklake district?
Me go now.
Me looking for help in me mission.
No thanks. Goodbye.
What I need is someone to assist me on a mission.
Bad stuff happens.
Well, that could happen to anyone.
Who be Sehameme Moonbutt?
I don't think I've ever heard of Sehanine Moonbow.
Nevermind.
Me want you to level up. You be better with training.
I'd like you to level up. You'd be more useful to me with a little training.
Me no want you here no more.
I think I'll do better off on my own.
No. Stay.
Yes. Go.
We need change way you do stuff.
Me not want change anything else now.
If me fail on locked door or chest you not help me.
If me fail on locked door or chest you help me.
You start sneak quiet now.
You stop sneaking so quiet now.
You search all time when we move.
You not search all time no more.
You need change how you heal me.
You change how far away you stay.
I think we need to change your tactics.
I don't want to change anything else right now.
If I fail to open a locked door or chest do not assist me.
If I fail to open a locked door or chest please come to my aid.
Could you stop being so stealthy all the time?
Could you use more stealth when we travel?
Could you please search when we move around?
Could you not search all the time?
Could we change how quickly you decide to heal me?
You heal if me hurt real bad (below 25% of total hit points).
You heal if me wounded (below 50% of total hit points).
You heal if me sort of hurt (below 75% of total hit points).
Heal me if I become seriously wounded (below 25% of total hit points).
Heal me if I become wounded (below 50% of total hit points).
Heal me if I become somewhat injured (below 75% of total hit points).
We need to change the distance you stay away from me.
Far distance.
Medium distance.
Stay close.
Me just wanna talk.
I just want to talk for a while.
Nevermind.
You got any hint or tip you give me 'bout this mission?
What you read?
What have you read?
Magic?
A ranger?
Me not want talk no more.
You know other stuff 'bout cult?
That's enough information for now.
Is there anything else you know about the cult?
Tell me 'bout Blacklake district.
Tell me about the Blacklake district.
Me not want talk no more.
I think that's enough talking for now.
Anything else?
Do you have any advice or suggestions you can give me about my mission?
Me want you to continue you story from before.
I want you to continue your story from before.
You no let stupid seed get in way of me important quest!
You no worry 'bout seed. We find and make goddess happy.
Me found strange seed! This be you seed?
No stupid seed had better get in the way of our important quest.
Don't worry Linu, we will find the seed, somehow.
I have an unusual seed right here. Is this it?
That be it? Not get anything new?
Me thank you for making it be stronger, Linu.
That's it? Nothing new?
Thank you for unlocking its full power, Linu.
What you do with seed now, Linu?
What will you do with the seed now, Linu?
And what 'bout you?
What about you?
I care for you as friend, more than any magic item.
Your friendship means more to me than any magical item.
No, and I really don't care. I think you're moving a little fast for me.
No, please tell me.
Yes, but I don't feel that way about you.
Yes. You complete me too, dear Linu.
I would like that very much.
Me change mind. Me no want hear you story.
I've changed my mind. I don't really want to hear this.
Tell me what they say.
Tell me what they said.
How long she look at tree for?
How long did she stand there looking at the trees?
What happen?
What happened?
You still be dreaming, maybe?
Are you sure you weren't still dreaming?
Floating?
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> Beauty standing amidst fiery destruction. That's you!
That amazing.
That's amazing.
People die all time, why goddess cry over stupid tree.
People die every day, but this goddess cries over a tree?
Where them go?
What happened to them?
Me could stare at you like that.
The way I could stand and admire your beauty for endless hours.
Me want hear it.
I want to hear it.
You get bored with magic stuff?
You were bored playing with magic items?
Go on.
Me think anyone else die if them was you.
I don't think anybody else could survive what you have.
Cursed.
Both, me think.
Both, I think.
It be blessing. Me like danger and beauty in woman.
I think it's a blessing. You are the most dangerous, yet exciting woman I have ever met.
Hey, me not look for true love, me just say nice words to friend.
Woah! Deeper relationship? It was just a compliment.
Then me not want to hear you story no more.
Then I don't want to listen to your whiny stories anymore.
Me not care what you think of me. We go now.
I really don't care what you think. Let's get going.
Me just make joke. You tell me you story, please.
I was just joking, Linu. Calm yourself and continue your story.
You go on with you story then.
Then let's continue your story.
So how you live?
So how did you survive?
What you do?
What did you see?
Who it be?
Who was it?
What voice say to you?
What did the voice say?
What she say?
What did she say?
How she make him stop?
How did she stop him?
Me knew that already.
I already figured that out.
No! You saved by goddess.
Wait, you were rescued by a goddess?
You need be glad she save you life!
How could you be ungrateful for such a gift?
A task?
That seem more than lucky to me.
That does seem to stretch the limits of luck.
You no blow place up, did you?
You didn't destroy the place, did you?
That's trouble.
What make you decide to become cleric?
What made you decide that you should be a cleric?
But you no be like them?
But you didn't take after them?
What be this 'potentials'?
What are 'potentials'?
Them were very wrong.
Boy, were they wrong.
Okay, tell more.
Okay, go on.
You be worse then than now.
I didn't think it was possible for you to be worse than you are now.
What you mean you move in?
What do you mean by moved in?
Me kick you out too, if you do such stupid thing.
I'd have kicked you out too, how stupid.
So he kick you out?
So he kicked you out?
Little trip?
What fate you talking 'bout?
What fate would that be?
Me want you keep talking 'bout story you start before.
I'd like you to tell me more of your story, Linu.
You no let thinking of husband get in way you job!
No worry, we find book and then we know what happen to you husband.
Me find book with you husband's name on it.
Just don't let this get in the way of your other duties.
Don't worry, we'll find the journal and discover what happened to your husband.
I found this journal. It has your husband's name on it.
Quit whining! Him dead long ago; you be over him.
Quit whining Linu. He's been dead for a long time, get over it.
You no stop now. You promise you help me, now you do!
Don't you back out on me now. You made a commitment and you had better fulfill it!
Me no leave you, Linu. You be strong and make Synth proud.
I won't leave you, Linu. You must be strong and go on, as Synth wanted you to.
It no you fault, Linu. Me no leave you.
It wasn't your fault, Linu. I'm not going to leave you.
That be it?
That be good reward. Me like pretty pendant.
That's it, huh?
That is a wonderful gift, Linu, thank you.
Temple no could party without you?
So? Why couldn't they do it without you?
Him no wait for you?
He wouldn't wait for you?
He keeping stuff like affair from you?
You figure he was fooling around on you?
Why you wish that?
Why is that?
Ten stories? You parents be rich?
Ten story wall? Your parent's must be rich.
What happen?
What happened?
Me be sure never to wake you at night.
Remind me never to try to wake you quietly in the night.
You break his jaw?
You mean you broke his jaw?
You just one bad thing after 'nother.
You're just one calamity after another, aren't you?
You didn't.
Tell me you didn't.
He live, I guess.
At least he survived.
That not burst his head open or stuff?
And that didn't kill him or turn him into a frog or something?
Him forgive you?
Did he forgive you?
What you mean by that?
You mean you... ?
Good move!
Ha, you bad luck kill him?
What? Did you kill him finally?
Why they not last? What happen?
What do you mean? What happened?
Good for you!
How you like being adventurer?
Tell me, how do you like being an adventurer?
Who that be?
Oh? Who is that?
YOU catch him for husband?
And YOU managed to hook him?
You husband.
Your husband.
You think you be pretty smart, huh?
Thought you were pretty smart, huh?
It be that bad?
Was it really that bad?
What he do?
What did he do?
Me want you continue you story from before.
Tell me more about your story.
You not let you search get in way of stuff you do for me!
If me find it me let you know.
Me found cup! This be cup you talk 'bout?
Just don't let your quest get in the way of mine. You work for me, not the other way around.
If I find it I'll let you know.
Is this the chalice you were talking about?
That's it? A pendant?
Thank you, Linu.
Why me ever pick you as friend, me just not know.
Why did I ever decide to pick you as a companion?
How you lose it?
How did you lose it?
How it possible you lose chalice again?
How in the name of all that is holy did you lose it again?
He have bad luck like you.
Sounds like he had just about as much luck as you do.
How you know this stuff?
How did you find all of this out?
That take real gall!
That just like a Zhent.
Me can't believe he did that!
Now that takes a lot of gall.
That's a Zhent for you.
I can't believe he would do that!
Old woman beat you up?
That terrible.
You got beat up by an old woman?
That's horrible.
Forget cup then. He probably sell it and you never find it 'gain.
You no worry Linu, me help you find cup.
Better forget about it then. He probably sold it and you'll never find it again.
Don't worry Linu, I'll help you find the chalice.
What about other priests?
You lost a gift from a goddess?
She show you city destroyed if you stay?
What you see in vision?
What, did she tell you to get the hell out of Evereska before you doomed them all?
What happened in the vision?
Me not used to calling other people slow, but...
It be good that they be very happy for you.
You're just a little clueless aren't you?
Yes, I'm sure they were very happy... for you.
Good. Me not paying you for you to quest! You here to keep me 'live and stuff!
Good. I'm paying you to keep me alive, not to worry about some stupid quest.
Me help you find it, Linu. We be good team.
We can find it, Linu, if we work together.
Me want help you, Linu.
Surely it has not failed. You will find it someday.
That be what thief took.
And that is what was stolen?
Me wanna know 'bout you, if we be working together.
If we're going to be working together, I'd like to know more about you.
What you remember 'bout you home?
What you problem with thieves be?
Why you leave you home?
What are your memories of your home like?
Them make fun of humans?
Me would have beat them up for being mean.
(Snicker) That be funny... I mean bad.
You have good times too, yes?
Do elven children really call each other humans, in a bad way?
I'd have beat some sense into them.
(Snicker) That's, um... terrible Linu.
There were good times too, right?
What happened to make you hate thieves so much?
Why did you leave your homeland?
You no bring bad luck to me! Me got 'nuff problems.
When me born, me mom dropped me on head. I got some bad luck too.
You'd better not bring any bad luck my way.
Well, bad luck happens to all of us at one time or other.
You be walking trouble. You no bring you troubles to me.
You really are a piece of work. You better not bring catastrophe down on me.
What did thief take?
What did the thief steal?
Fine. You no let you problems get in me way.
It okay, Linu. Me want know what you talking about.
Fine, just don't let your problems get in my way.
No, Linu. I want to hear what you had to say.
IGNORE THIS STARTING CONDITION. THIS IS USED AS A TRASH FOR UNWANTED LINKS. DO NOT DELETE THESE LINKS.
My goal in life is to get through with a minimum of pain, but sometimes one has to aim for simple survival. To achieve that, you will need an experienced healer.
I promise I will do my best to keep you in excellent health. Only 250 gold pieces and you will gain the talents of one who can heal and fight.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> I'm sorry. 250 is my final offer. Consider the cost of repeated journeys to a temple for healing.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Perhaps we could meet in the middle and settle on 225?
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> I guess I must not let my race's prejudices get in the way. 200 is fair; all my skills are yours to command.
I promise I will do my best to keep you in excellent health. Only 200 gold pieces and you will gain the talents of one who can heal and fight.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> I'm sorry. 200 is my final offer. Consider the cost of repeated journeys to a temple for healing.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Perhaps we could meet in the middle and settle on 175?
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> You seem like an agreeable <man/woman> to work with, dear <FirstName>. 150 it is, and all my skills are yours to command.

I promise I will do my best to keep you in excellent health. You have a pleasant and trustworthy demeanor, so I will reduce my normal fee. Only 150 gold pieces and you will gain the talents of one who can heal and fight.
Nobody owns me, dear. You have paid for my skills. There is a subtle, yet important difference.
Goddess speed your journey and keep you safe. If you have need of my skills, I shall be here, unless someone else hires me.
Ah well, maybe in time you will earn the funds and can return. I just hope you don't have to spend it all on healing from the temples. Is there something else you need?
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> I'm sorry. 150 is my final offer. Consider the cost of repeated journeys to a temple for healing.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Perhaps we could meet in the middle and settle on 125?
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> You seem like an agreeable <man/woman> to work for. 100 it is, and all my skills are yours to command.
You will not regret this, dear <FirstName>. My skills are yours to command.
I will follow you and perform to the best of my abilities, according to the orders you have given me. Any time you wish to issue new orders you have only to speak to me again.

I promise I will do my best to keep you in excellent health. Since we're both of the <race> race I'm willing to cut my normal fee. Only 150 gold pieces and you will gain the talents of one who can heal and fight.
Sorry dear, but I serve another master now. There's nothing else I can do for you.
I hoped that you would return, so I waited here. I've hardly damaged anything since you left; I thought you'd be proud. May I join with you once more, my friend?
(Sigh) Then I shall wait here for you to return.
I shall try to breathe life back into you and your quest.

I can still feel my death, hanging on me, cold and eerie. I am glad to be back in this mortal realm again. Now that I know how it feels, I will struggle even harder to keep you from that fate. May I join you again, <FirstName>?
(Sigh) Then I shall wait here for you to return.
I shall try to breathe life back into you and your quest.
I see we meet again, <FirstName>. Would you be looking for a powerful healer? I would gladly join in the search for the Words of Power.
Hello there, <FullName>. The bards sing of your exploits in the taverns these days. It's a thrill to finally meet you.
Well, I guess humility isn't something they'll praise in songs about you. Still, you have accomplished great deeds and saved many lives.
It may be duty that drives you, but without your actions, many innocents would now be dead.
My name is Linu La'neral, an elven cleric of Sehanine Moonbow. I believe you are here on the same mission Aarin Gend hired all the mercenaries for: to find the Words of Power.
Good luck then. If you find yourself spending too much time and gold at the temple, return and speak with me again.
Yes, there are many mercenaries here, hired to aid him in this cause. We seek the Words of Power throughout the north, to stop them from falling into the enemy's hands.
I have been working in Neverwinter to save those stricken with the plague. It was a grim and endless task, and I will do everything in my power to save all people from suffering any more.

I am a skilled healer, and I would love to discover clues to this mystery, but I fear to do so on my own <FirstName>. I would like to have the security of someone to watch my back. I would love to help you, if you need a healer.
Good luck then. If you find yourself spending too much time and gold at the temple, return and speak with me again.
I will follow you and perform to the best of my abilities, according to the orders you have given me. Any time you wish to issue new orders you have only to speak to me again.
I don't know where they would be, although I would think that such magic would most likely be associated with the ancient times. That leads me to think about some ruins, far to the south of here.
I have read lately of ruins that contain traces of ancient cultures, whose knowledge of magic ran deeper than any living today.
I am an elf of Evereska, a land where studying the mysteries is more than a path, it is the highest calling. The ruins to the south call to me, as if they hide knowledge that is imperative to us all.
I suppose that it may just be my own heritage, driving me to study something as old and unusual as these ruins are reputed to be, but it might be even more than that.
My dear friend, <FirstName>. It warms my heart to see your face again. Aarin Gend must have brought you here to help search for the Words of Power.
I don't know what your problem is today, <FirstName>, but come speak to me again when you've found some manners.
After Aribeth's betrayal I readied myself for a return to Evereska. Yet somewhere deep inside, I prayed that we would meet once more, <FirstName>.

When I heard of Aarin Gend's call for brave adventurers to serve the cause of Neverwinter to join the Lords' Alliance here at Beorunna's Well, I knew that you could not resist such a grand opportunity.
You are drawn to heroic deeds, like a glutton to a bakery, <FirstName>. I grabbed the first ride out of town and came here. Well... the second ride actually got me here.
Well, if that is the way you feel, <FirstName>. I... I hope you change your mind. I think the goddess has brought me here to help you.
Then I shall endeavor to keep you alive once again, <FirstName>. Just try, occasionally, to keep out of harm's way. Sometimes I think you are as bad as I am for getting in trouble.
I don't know where they would be, although I would think that such magic would most likely be associated with the ancient times. That leads me to think about some ruins, far to the south of here.
I have read lately of ruins that contain traces of ancient cultures, whose knowledge of magic ran deeper than any living today.
I am an elf of Evereska, a land where studying the mysteries is more than a path, it is the highest calling. The ruins to the south call to me, as if they hide knowledge that is imperative to us.
I suppose that it may just be my own heritage, driving me to study something as old and unusual as these ruins are reputed to be, but it might be even more than that.
I will follow your lead as always, my dear <FirstName>. You are a better judge of such things than I am.
You make it sound as if, oh... all right, nevermind.
I was supposed to hitch a ride with one of the supply wagons at first, but the wagon I was on... broke.
Well... we had stopped for the night and I... I had this nightmare that a dragon was chasing me.
I woke up out of the dream, and saw something large outlined against the moon. I should have known better, it didn't really look like a dragon, but I was frightened.
So I cast the first spell that came to mind. The first blast of lightning did a little damage, but it was the following three that shattered it to little tiny pieces.
(Sigh) Yes, I seem to go to great lengths to cause trouble.
It was dark and everyone was so shocked by the lightning that no one knew where it came from. I suppose that I probably should have told them it was me.
I had to get here though, and I will pay Lord Nasher back out of my own wages when we are done here.
Hello again, <FirstName>. I do hope you remember me. I'm Linu La'neral, cleric of Sehanine Moonblade.
I'm just waiting here so I can help someone bring those evil plague spreaders to justice.
Greetings and well met. You are <FullName>, aren't you? You saved the city of Neverwinter. I heard the tales of your deeds as they were sung by a bard. It's wonderful to meet you in person.
I am Linu La'neral, an elven priestess of Sehanine Moonbow. I was hoping to meet you, but I figured I missed you while I was changing my clothes.
If you find yourself spending a lot of time with the temple healers, you might want to come back here and hire me. Good luck.
Oh, when I came in here a waitress spilled some drinks.
Well... no. I bumped into her and when the drinks crashed down I leapt backwards into a dwarf, knocking over his ale and stew.
Um, no, the food and drinks landed on the floor, but the dwarf crashed into a half-orc, causing the knife he was eating with to slice open his cheek. That's when the brawl started.
I managed to stay out of the brawl, hiding under a table and feeling awfully guilty. When the fight was over I felt I should help clean up the mess.
No, I wore an apron and managed to stay pretty clean. Then I stepped outside for a breath of fresh air and slipped in a mud puddle. So then I had to go change.
Oh, please don't leave now. I didn't want to frighten you away.
I... I didn't want you to think I was clumsy.
I'm waiting here at the orders of Lady Aribeth.
Yes, I know that already. Are you sure it was you who figured out how the plague was started?
Lord Nasher ordered all mercenaries to come to Port Llast to help discover the whereabouts of the cult that nearly destroyed his city.
I spent weeks wearing myself out, trying to help ease the suffering of plague victims. I jumped at the opportunity to bring the culprits to justice.
I'm not much of an investigator. I have been ordered to travel with anyone who has need of a healer.
You are the one who knows how to solve mysteries, <FirstName>. I would love to help you though.
I have strong abilities in the art of healing, and I also can stand on my own in a fight. I would be a valuable resource for your quest.
It would be a great pleasure, <FirstName>. I look forward to our adventures together.
I will follow you and perform to the best of my abilities, according to the orders you have given me. Any time you wish to issue new orders you have only to speak to me again.
I haven't heard anything specific about the cult, but I have heard about some trouble around Neverwinter Wood.
I don't know very much, but apparently there was a ranger in town here that was telling of animals savagely attacking anyone in or around the woods.

Having failed to destroy us with their terrible disease, it would hardly shock me to find out that the cult had struck with a plague of vicious animals. Is there anything else I can help you with, <FirstName>?
Modesty is a true sign of a heroic nature. I think that the bards will sing more than one song about your deeds someday.
<FirstName>! I had hoped that you would show up here, my friend. I heard that Aribeth recruited you to stamp out the evil cult that was responsible for the plague.
You certainly know how to flatter yourself, <FirstName>, but I did not follow you here. I have my own goals and reasons for needing to be here.
I thought we had parted for good, <FirstName>, but the goddess has her own plans that I must follow.
I went back to the Trade of Blades to prepare myself for a journey home. I was only there a few hours when I was approached by Lady Aribeth on behalf of Lord Nasher himself.
