How is you part of story, huh?
How are you involved in all this?
Of course, of course.
Well, actually, Sir Karathis just hired me and my friends to help him. He was the hunter, after all...
Well, I have no direct part in the tale, <sir/madam>. I travel wherever tales of lycanthropes abound, hoping my goods will aid in their destruction.
People here are quite worried about this Black Wolf, naturally, so the anti-lycanthropic business has been good. Ander, here, has been very helpful.
Nope, me not wants that.
No thanks.
Yeah, you tells me.
Yes, tell me.
You tells me about werewolf you meets.
Tell me about your encounter with the werewolf.
What werewolf? What you says?
What's this about a werewolf?
You helps sell what?
Werewolf remedies?
What you goings to do, now?
What do you plan on doing now?
Yeah, you is useless, for sure.
Yes, you're pretty useless, all right.
You makes money when you helps Alhelor, huh?
You must have made some money helping Alhelor, no?
Then you is dumb kid! Hah!
Then you're an idiot. Hah!
Is good. You gives me coin and you nots get hurt.
Good. Hand over the coin, then, and be quick about it.
Me thinks you should go, then, maybe.
I think you should move on, then.
You kids me? You not finds way out of town! Ha ha!
Are you kidding? You couldn't find your way out of town!
Here... me gives 100 gold to helps out.
Here... 100 gold to help you out.
Okays. You do that.
You do that.
Maybe you coulds sell stuff now?
Maybe you should open your own shop?
Hah! Me jokes! You never does that!
Hah! I was joking! As if you could ever do it!
Oh. Is there something else you wanted, then?
Oh. Well... if you're looking for Alhelor, then, you missed him.
If you want to ask them about Urth, they live on the south side of town. Just... don't say anything about me.
I know it sounds silly. I... met a werewolf myself, though, and if Alhelor's goods can help fight them, then I'm proud to help him.
I don't know. I'm a bit confused. Angry, too. I can't believe Alhelor tricked us all like that! I thought he really wanted to help kill werewolves.
I feel so stupid. Worse, now I've got nothing to do... my friends are all dead, and I can't help Alhelor run his shop anymore, obviously. (sigh)
I... I guess...
Ex-excuse me... maybe I should... maybe I should go...
Just... just a little bit. I helped him mostly for the experience.
What? You're... you're robbing me? Is there nobody decent in this world? F-fine! T-take it! Take it all!
You mean leave Port Llast? I... I guess you're right. Maybe I should, there's nothing for me here...
A... hundred gold? That's so generous of you, my <lord/lady>. I... I can't thank you enough for your help. Bless you!
Thank you! Thank you, <sir/madam>... you've been a great help!
Open my own shop...? I... I suppose I could. Alhelor must still have some of his supplies somewhere. Yes... yes, maybe I will!
I'm sorry, <sir/madam>, but I really must go...
Get away, you. I'm just here for a drink, not to be harassed by your ilk.
I don't have time to talk to the likes of you, sorry. You could be one of them werewolves around here, for all I know.
You strike me as one of those bandits you find on the road everywhere, nowadays. Hmph.
It's a good thing the plague in Neverwinter is over. If it went on any longer, the city would be too weak and there'd be war for sure!
You'd best be careful on the roads. We gots werewolves in these parts... and I hear there's monster bandits all over the northern routes.
Pleased to meet you, <sir/madam>. Don't remember seeing you in Port Llast before now.
I certainly hope you find the people responsible for the plague. What monster could do such a thing?!
You're with Lady Aribeth, aren't you? Maybe you could do something about our werewolves while you're here.
Are... are you that hero from Neverwinter that's here with Lady Aribeth? So wonderful to meet you!
I don't suppose there's a chance you'd buy me a drink, handsome?
(sigh) I knew there had to be big, strong men like you somewhere.
My, my. Hello there, handsome.
If I knew this tavern had women like you about, I'd travel this way more often.
My, my... didn't expect to see any fine-looking lasses like yourself in Port Llast...
Greetings, lass. You're a fine-lookin' woman, aren't you? Care for a drink?
We don't see much <race> folk like you in Port Llast. Mostly humans, here, you see.
You know, I heard you <race> folk are what caused that plague.
More <race> folk, is it? What, did you all decide to up and leave Neverwinter, now?
Err... we don't get many barbarians coming through Port Llast, usually...
You barbarians do know how to behave in a tavern, right?
What's that smell? It's like... bear dung, or something...
Please put that away, <sir/madam>. It makes me nervous.
Isn't there a policy in the taverns against walking around with a weapon out?
I really wish you wouldn't wave that thing about in here.
Where did you get all those wounds?
That's quite the lot of cuts you've got there. Must have been quite a fight.
Those wounds of yours don't look good. Shouldn't you get them treated?
Are you mad, running about without proper clothing?
What's this? Another half-naked refugee from Neverwinter?
Err... you always run around taverns without your clothes, do you?
Goodbye.
What you doings here, then?
What are you doing here, then?
You help me by give me gold maybe?
Maybe you can help me another way. I need gold for expenses.
Me gotta go now.
I better go.
You give me gold or me cut off you sick leg.
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> Aribeth tell me to get money for search, so you give.
Okay, but me ask more question now.
You had better hand over some gold, before I have to perform surgery to remove that diseased leg.
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> Lady Aribeth has commanded me to raise funds to assist the search.
All right, I would like to ask you more questions though.
Aye, fare ye well, <lad/lass>... an' good luck.
Well, since I were ambushed along the north road, my bum knee's been keepin' me grounded. I found out some, though... maybe I could be of help to ye.
Well, I should like to <Lad/Lass>, but I need all me gold to feed meself and keep a roof over me head. No income comin' in with a bum leg and all.
Just don't forget to come back and tell me what's happenin'. Maybe I can help ye make sense of it all.
The leg is hurt, it doesn't need... oh, I get it. Well, if it's gonna be that way, I guess I could come up with a little gold. Here's 100 gold, but that's all I have.
Just remember me generosity when ye come back. I want to hear what be goin' on, what with me bein' unable to get around proper.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> I be tellin' ye, I can't be givin' gold away when I be wounded like this.
I'd be more than happy to help ye puzzle this quest out though. You just come back when somethin' happens and I'll try to help ye out.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> To help catch the cult ye say, well I suppose I could give ye 100 gold pieces. I'll find some way to feed meself.
What do ye want to know?
Me need healing.
I need healing.
Who you be?
Who are you?
Me not understand 'bout Stone of Recall and teleport portal.
Teleportation portal? Stone of Recall? I don't understand.
That's handy.
Me need you go over that one more time.
Can you explain that again?
Goodbye.
Me need to return to mission. Me need to go back to place where me died.
How me get here?
I need to return to my mission. I must get back to where I just was.
What you suggest?
What do you suggest?
Me think you're right. Goodbye.
I think you're right. I'll see you later.
Teleport portal? Recall Stone? What you be talking about?
Teleportation portal? Stone of Recall? What are you talking about?
That's handy.
You got bad attitude. Me want go back now!
Save the sarcasm and just get me back there.
Me change my mind. Goodbye.
I've changed my mind. I'll see you later.
Yes. Me want to go back now.
Yes. Transport me there now.
Just do it.
How did I get here?
Me no trust you Recall spell! You take spell off me now!
You say me be fully healed?
I don't want your stupid Word of Recall spell teleporting me anywhere. Cancel the spell, right now!
How me get back where me be before?
So how am I supposed to get back to where I was?
You mean I'm fully healed?
Me no remember you cast spell on me.
How come I don't remember you casting a Recall spell on me?
Who you be?
Who are you?
Hello <FirstName>. I hope your deeds in Neverwinter weren't a fluke. Aribeth has a lot of time and energy invested in you.
But don't expect me to go healing you or anything like that. My powers are tied to the teleportation portal and the Stone of Recall in your backpack.

You know, I pray to Tyr several times a day, pleading that I won't have days like this. "Please Lord," I beg, "don't try my patience today. Send only adventurers who are smart and understand that I don't heal them," yet it never happens.
Go speak to Neurik. As I already said, my abilities are tied stritctly to the Word of Recall and the teleportation portal. He's the healer. Is there anything else I can do for you, <FirstName>?
My name is Caliandros, a cleric of Tyr. I serve Aribeth by aiding those who work for her.

You mean you haven't figured that out yet? What did they do, put a pot on your head, a stick in your hand and tell you to go save Neverwinter? I would expect more preparation, but I guess I'll tell you about it.
In your backpack you carry a Stone of Recall. You can activate this stone at anytime and it will instantly teleport you and anyone in your service back to this temple.
This will allow you to quickly return to town whenever you need to, saving precious travelling time.
There is more, <FirstName>. Once you have used the stone, go through the teleportation portal and it will instantly send you back to the place your stone was last activated.
Anyone in your service - henchmen, familiars and the like - will also be transported with you. Now, is there anything else I can do for you, <FirstName>?
You had better be more careful. I used up a lot of energy bringing you back. I wasn't even sure you were going to make it.
Goodbye <FirstName>. Tyr protect you.
I can send you back there, no problem, but then you'll just get chopped, chomped, or crushed again and then I have to bring you right back here.

Why don't you consider getting better armor, or weapons here in town first? Or maybe you could try to go a different way than you just did. Or would you like to rush right back into certain death again?
You could also use the teleportation portal to take you back to where you last activated the stone of recall.

You mean you haven't figured that out yet? What did they do, put a pot on your head, a stick in your hand and tell you to go save Neverwinter? I would expect more preparation, but I guess I'll tell you about it.
In your backpack you carry a Stone of Recall. You can activate this stone at any time and it will instantly teleport you and anyone in your service back to this temple.
This will allow you to return quickly to town whenever you need to, saving precious traveling time.
There is more, <FirstName>. Once you have used the stone, go through the teleportation portal and it will instantly send you back to the place your stone was last activated.
Anyone in your service - henchmen, familiars and the like - will also be transported with you. Now, is there anything else I can do for you, <FirstName>?
Like I should be surprised. All right, I can use a spell called Dimensional Fold. It will return you to your last battle. Are you ready?
Okay. Ready yourself.
You mean nobody told you? Fine, I guess I get to explain it to you.
Aribeth has been very impressed with the job you have been doing so far, so she has asked me to watch over you; to keep you alive. That's a difficult job, thank you very much.

I cast a Word of Recall spell upon you before you started this mission, so that every time you run around getting swords and arrows and such shot into your body, I can teleport your body back here and bring you back again.
Obviously you weren't being careful enough, probably stepped into a hole with big signs around it saying 'Don't step here', and when you broke your neck, the contingency magic swept you back here.
I can't even begin to express how tempting that notion is, but Aribeth's orders were very strict. You are considered too important to her mission.
I thought about leaving you to bleed to death, but Tyr frowns on that sort of thing, so I had the other clerics heal you.
You should be ready to run off and get yourself killed again in no time. The Recall spell will continue to bring you back to me, each time your body gets mangled enough.
I couldn't see that question coming. All I need to know is your full name, which Aribeth provided, and I can cast the spell without your presence.
My name is Caliandros, a cleric of Tyr. I serve Aribeth by aiding those who work for her, though I'm not a healer.
I see you are finally awake. Well, get over here. I need to speak to you.
We are very disappointed in you, <FirstName>. Your slaughter of innocent people has caused much suffering in a time already overburdened with tragedy.
Were it up to me you would have been left to rot in your grave; however, Aribeth has ordered me to resurrect you. Despite your actions, Neverwinter still has need of you.
You will suffer no further consequences for your mad killing spree, but I implore you not to engage in such wholesale slaughter again. Please, focus on the mission you have been given.
Goodbye.
'Nuff dumb talkin'. You answer me questions.
Me feel terrible.
Me fine, thank you.
Enough with the chit chat, I have some questions for you.
We need talk 'bout gold.
What you know 'bout evil cult?
You tell me where stuff be?
What happen round here?
We need to talk about finances.
Give me you gold, or you farm with broken leg.
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> Aribeth send me to get gold, so you give.
Give me some gold or you'll be harvesting with a broken leg.
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> Lady Aribeth has sent me to collect a special tax to help finance the search for the cult.
Goodbye.
Um, sorry, nevermind.
What do you know about the cult that started the plague?
Can you give me directions?
What's going on around here?
No clue.
Uh, sure.
I feel terrible.
I'm fine, thank you.
Me want talk 'bout different things.
Why me sad 'bout weather?
I want to talk about something else.
Why would I be depressed about the weather?
Hello there. How are you today good <master/mistress>?
Take care young <man/woman>. May Chauntea favor you with predictable weather.
What can I help you with?
I don't have time to talk about gold, I have to spend all my time just trying to make a little. It's getting so a man can't afford to feed his kids anymore.
Please no! My family depends on my farming to survive the winters. I'll give you 50 gold, just let me alone.
Never did trust you wandering adventurer types. Heroes... bah!
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Well, that's just too dang bad, cause I gotta be able to feed my kids and if I give you any money then they'll starve.
You go tell the Lady she can come talk to me in person and I'll let her see how skinny my kids are. Plague or starvation, either way we're dead.
Yeah, goodbye.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Oh, well, I guess I have a few moldy potatoes left in the root cellar that we can survive on until I can earn some more money. Here's fifty gold; it's all I have though.
Now I'd better get to work. Just hope the weather doesn't kill my crop or we'll all starve this winter.
Somebody already took my gold, so you can just go find someone else to beg from.
I'd like to take my scythe to them and cut 'em short at the bloody kneecaps, that's what I know about them. Anything else?

I don't have time to be a road map and this town's not really all that big. I've got planting and feeding and milking and all sorts of jobs that need done. Don't suppose you're looking to settle down and be a farmhand?
No, I don't suppose. You adventuring types are always in such a rush. Anything else I can help you with?
There's all kinds of excitement in town with the hunt for this dang, plague-spreading cult. Adventurers wander around, trampling across crops and ruining many a good farmer's daughter.
Not that I don't think the cult ought be uprooted, but there's a proper way to do things, you know what I mean?
Well that's the problem with you young people today, running around like a chicken with its head cut off, no clue about what's going on around you.
I guess you probably have other questions you need answered, what with your lack of any common sense at all.
Then of course there's all the damage to the community that's caused when all the young folk here get it in their heads that they can be adventurers too.
Off they go, gettin' themselves into trouble or killed, and then who's to take over when their fathers are ready to retire. No sir, I don't sit right proper with all these adventuring folk, I don't.
You should take a piece of advice and settle down, raise a family and make an honest living. But don't mind me, nobody else does. Any other questions?
Ah, now, that's the way things go. You're probably depressed about the weather and I don't blame you one bit.
Well, that's good to hear. I thought with the weather being the way it is, you might have been depressed. How may I help you?

Well, if it rains too much then we'll be flooded out, but if it doesn't rain enough then we'll have a drought. Any way you look at it, we farmers are going to suffer, and if we suffer, then there's no food.
That means prices of goods skyrocket in the cities. I figured that might depress you. But enough gloom and doom, how can I help you today?
You're the <lad/lass> that killed those rampaging creatures to the north of here, aren't ya? Sure enough I've heard lots of heroic stuff about you!
Now, I hear tell that you went and stopped the wild attacks of the creatures from the Neverwinter Wood. Good job, I say.
I don't have time to speak to you anymore.
Goodbye.
Me have questions to ask you.
Why you say that?
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> Me seen lots with job collecting taxes.
I see lots in me adventures.
I have some questions to ask you.
Me need job.
Me need find stuff.
You hear strange stuff lately?
I am looking for work.
I need directions.
That's it. Goodbye.
Me want ask different thing.
I want to ask you something else.
Where me get healed?
Where me buy good stuff?
Where can I get healed?
Where can I get some equipment?
Path to destruction?
Have you heard anything unusual lately?
Anything else?
Why do you say that?
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> As a tax collector I get to visit with a variety of people.
Sorry, me mistake. Me ask you some questions.
You be working for cult if you no give gold to help hunt them.
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> Me get gold to help Lady Aribeth hunt cult.
Sorry, nevermind. I want to ask you some questions.
Only someone who is in league with the cult we are hunting would refuse to give gold to help.
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> I work for Lady Aribeth, and I am collecting gold to help hunt down the cult that started the plague in Neverwinter.
I have seen a lot in my adventures.
Good <day/night> to you, <sir/madam>. You look like the kind of person who has seen many interesting things.
Happy travels to you <sir/madam>.
I would love to help you out in any way I can. Some people in town might be standoffish, but I believe in a no-secrets policy.
You should go talk to Mayor Kendrack. He's been worried about something, though I'm not sure what. He tries awfully hard to keep Port Llast running. Anything else?
Oh, I know where everything is in town. It's a precious little town, isn't it? Too bad we're on a path to destruction.

There is an underground temple to Tyr. Just find a glowing portal and enter it. The priest is a good man. He's helped a lot of people. I just wish he could lead us off of this path to destruction. Anything else?

The Cracked Anvil has all the best equipment an adventurer could ask for. That would probably be your best bet. I hope that one of my sons will get a job there, as soon as they can count. Anything else?
I certainly would say so. There is a very unusual ranger, hiding out in a grove of trees here in town. He is telling the strangest tales about animal attacks. It's a bad sign for us, I say.

There are tales of werewolves running around and biting people. It just goes to show, the world is going mad. I was telling my friend the other day, that the world is on a path to destruction, no doubt about it.
Those are the only strange things that I can think of. Is there anything else I can help you with?
Oh, no offense meant. I just thought you had the look of one who has traveled; just like I know everything that goes on around here.
Oh, a um... tax collector. I guess I should be getting back to the children now.
No! They would throw me in jail, or kill me and then my children would surely starve to death.
I guess I could give you 50 gold. Poor little Sally will just have to keep wearing those shoes that pinch her feet and Billy can make do without a birthday gift this year.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> I can't afford to give my gold away. I have sick, starving children that need the little bit of gold we have. Find someone else to steal from.

<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Well, I guess I could give you 50 gold to help you out. Little Sally will just have to keep wearing those shoes that pinch her feet and Billy can make do without a birthday gift this year.
I must get back to my children. Now that I can't afford the cost of medicine for little Mary, I will just hope I can nurse her through this illness.
I already paid the last tax collector, so you'll have to find a different mark.
I bet you have, just like I have seen pretty much everything that happens in this town.
I guess you're one of the heroes who cleaned the monsters out of the caves to the North. Keep the good work up.
You must be the hero who made the Neverwinter Wood safe again. We're all proud of you around here.
I don't have time to speak to you. I have too many mouths to feed to stand around gossiping.
The sign explains that this monument was built to commemorate the founding of Port Llast. The eternally glowing lights serve to welcome visitors to the town.
Maybe, but me want ask 'nother question.
Me do that. Bye bye.
Me not need nothing.
I need nothing at this time.
Who Haljal?
Who is Haljal?
Me want see what you sell.
Let me see what you have.
Greetings, <race>. I be Haljal's smith. If ye need some arms or armor and cannot find what ye like in Haljal's regular stock, I may be able to help ye.
Haljal Throndor be the owner of this shop and me boss. The man by the counter. Do ye want arms or not? Haven't got all day.
As ye wish.
I wish you well on your quest to find the source of that horrible plague. I am sure that you will succeed and prove to be a hero once again. Goodbye!
Intruder! Destroy! Destroy!
He learned of his error shortly thereafter. Beware of trolls.
<Race>! Die!
Me eat your eyes!
As a druid, you can challenge me, but you have to talk to Jaer first.
Why have you come to Setara?
Rend your flesh and suck the marrow from your bones, will I!
South: Charwood
Forest of Charwood
Someone has scratched the word 'BEWARE' into the sign.
This ancient tree seems to pulse with energy, as if it is sentient.
Me want know 'bout dem peoples.
Tell me about the different people around here.
Who would you like to know about?
Mayor Mobley hasn't told me to let anyone through. You'd better speak to him in his office at the center of town.
To South road and Port Llast
Danford Q. Mobley Mayor of Charwood Since 1172
Me has no time to be errand <boy/girl>.
I've no time for your errands.
I would like some directions.
Me needs directions.
Nevermind.
Me told there be caves 'round here.
I'm told there are caves in this area.
Me looks for Luskan. Is this way?
Can you tell me the way to Luskan?
Me just wants find inn.
Where's the nearest inn?
Is okay, thanks.
That's fine, thanks.
Me gots no more questions.
I don't have any more questions.
You thinks wife lives, maybe?
Do you think your wife is still alive?
You knows about cult 'round here, maybe?
Do you know anything about a cult in the region?
Where me finds caves?
Where do I find these caves?
Tell me 'bout Dergiab.
Tell me of this Dergiab.
What you wants me to do again?
What is it you want me to do again?
Me not needs gold. Me happy to help.
No reward is necessary. I was glad to do it.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Safety of wife be worth more, no?
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> I think your wife's safety is worth more than that, no?
Me not take gold for sad news.
I cannot accept your gold for bringing such sad news.
Me thinks you give more gold. Me not be nice, otherwise.
I think you can cough up a bit more. Wouldn't want to get rough.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Peace of minds worth more, no?
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> I think peace of mind is worth a bit more, no?
Nevermind.
Me told there be caves 'round here.
I'm told there are caves in this area.
Is okay, thanks.
That's fine, thanks.
Why you not just leaves?
Why don't you just leave?
Why Luskan stops patrols?
Why would Luskan stop patrolling?
Who this Dergiab?
Who is this Dergiab?
You knows Aarin Gend?
You know Aarin Gend?
What you says about wife?
What's this about your wife?
Maybe me coulds help.
Perhaps I could help.
Me gots other stuff to do.
I have other things to do.
Me looks into it real soon, then.
I will look into it as soon as I can.
Me has questions.
I have some questions.
Me gots no more questions.
I don't have any more questions.
You thinks wife lives, maybe?
Do you think your wife is still alive?
You knows about cult 'round here, maybe?
Do you know anything about a cult in the region?
Where me finds caves?
Where do I find these caves?
Tell me 'bout Dergiab.
Tell me of this Dergiab.
How much reward you means?
What kind of reward are we talking?
There be other adventurers, huh?
There have been other adventurers?
What you does here?
What is it you do around here?
You be Gerrol? Me talks with son.
You're Gerrol? Your son mentioned you.
Me not agrees to nothings, yet.
Not so fast, old man.
He thinks so, yup.
He seemed to think so, yes.
What kind of help you needs?
What kind of help do you need?
As you wish, <lad/lass>. I was only asking. If you do discover something, please do tell me.
I suppose so. What are you looking for?
Something else old Gerrol can do for you, then, <lad/lass>?
Aye. Plenty of caves in these parts, and full of creatures of all sorts. Nearest entrance is in the hills just to the north.
I wouldn't go wandering about the hills here, though, unless you're prepared to fight. The creatures sure will be.
It's not much farther to the north, <lad/lass>. Just keep on the road an' you'll find it, sure enough.
I can tell you right now that you're wasting your time. Luskan is shut up tight... they'll just send you to wait at the Green Griffon Inn, is all. It's up to you, though.
Well, the closest inn would the Alliance Arms Inn in Port Llast. That shouldn't take you too much time to get to.
Other than that, the only inn I can think of would be the Green Griffon Inn outside of Luskan, to the north past the hills.
If you're really strapped, you're more'n welcome to stay here in my farm. There's not much I can offer you, however, <lad/lass>.
Aye? I'll answer whatever I can, <lad/lass>.
Fair enough. Like I said, I'll give you what reward I can, if you help me out. It's the same offer I've made to any other adventurer that's come by.
I... I certainly hope so, <lad/lass>. It all depends on what Dergiab wants with his prisoners. I've braced myself for the worst, to be honest.
A cult? You mean in connection to Dergiab and these creatures? Hmm. Can't say that I do, really... though that'd explain Dergiab's sudden ambition.
To be honest, I always thought Dergiab fashioned himself as a bit of a god amongst them other monsters. I'd be surprised if he allied with anyone else. You never know, however.
There's a few of them spread out in the hills. They all connect together underground in a large warren, however... be sure you don't get lost.
There's one entrance in the hills just north of here. Most like Dergiab's followers will find you before you find them.
Well, he's an ogre mage... smarter than his brutish cousins and a fair bit more powerful, too. He can become invisible and has plenty of spells, I'd say.
Dergiab's led a lot of the other creatures for quite some time, now. Never been brave enough to really do anything drastic, however... I'm not sure why he would start now.
I told you this already, didn't I, <lad/lass>? I suppose there's no harm in repeating the tale.

The hills in this area are home to creatures of all sorts... bugbears, goblins and the like. Normally they don't trouble us much. Since Luskan stopped patrolling the area, they've become plenty brave.
For weeks, now, they've been attacking anyone passing through these parts. Attacked the farm a few times, too... that's when they made off with my wife, Leah.
All of this is likely the doing of the leader of them monsters, Dergiab. No one will be safe until he's dead. You bring me word of my wife or his head... I'll reward you for either.
Thank you, <lad/lass>, for bringing me a bit of peace of mind. I hope this bit of gold will suffice for the trouble you've taken.
You... you are a good <man/woman>, <lad/lass>. I appreciate it.
Hmph. I don't remember adventuring being about bullying the common man. But have it your way... here. It is all I can afford.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> I have little enough left to give you, <lad/lass>. My wealth from my adventuring days is long gone.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Aye, perhaps you are right. Here, <lad/lass>... let me give you a little more, then. It is all I have.
Is there something else, <lad/lass>?
Aye, do be careful if you go into the hills, then, <lad/lass>. I wish you well.
Something else old Gerrol can do for you, then, <lad/lass>?
Aye. Plenty of caves in these parts, and full of creatures of all sorts. Nearest entrance is in the hills just to the north.
I wouldn't go wandering about the hills here, though, unless you're prepared to fight. The creatures sure will be.
I can tell you right now that you're wasting your time. Luskan is shut up tight... they'll just send you to wait at the Green Griffon Inn, is all. It's up to you, though.
If you're really strapped, you're more'n welcome to stay here in my farm. There's not much I can offer you, however, <lad/lass>.
For weeks, now, they've been attacking anyone passing through these parts. Attacked the farm a few times, too... that's when they made off with my wife.
I figure it's all that Dergiab's doing. Damn ogre will get what's coming to him one way or another, I swear it!
I would gladly head to the city until things settle down. I won't leave without my wife, Leah, however... or at least until I know for sure what happened to her.
And failing that, I'll make sure Dergiab pays for crossing me an' mine. That's why I sent the boy to Port Llast to find adventurers... one of them folk should be able to do something.
You haven't heard? Since Neverwinter had its plague, that Luskan's gone and shut their walls up tight. No one goes in, no one comes out.
I never liked their soldiers much... like bandits, sometimes, the way they act. Since they stopped patrolling, however, it makes you realize what worse things they kept in check.
If Luskan was keeping order, Dergiab never would've gotten it in his head to make his move... and my wife would still be here.
Dergiab is an ogre mage... a rather cunning sort who's decided he's just the critter to lead all these other monsters.
How he got it into his head I haven't a clue, but from what I can tell he's gone and built himself an army. What he intends to do with it scares me just a little.
I went and sent a warning off to my old friend Aarin Gend, but I haven't heard back from him yet. I s'pose he's got more important things on his plate right now, all things considered.
Aye, I do. An old friend, I said. You don't think I've spent my whole life as a farmer, do you? Ha! We all settle down some day, <lad/lass>.
If I were in my younger days, I'd go into those caves and find Leah for myself. I wish I could. As it stands, I'll have to wait for some younger adventurer to take up the task for me.
Leah is her name. She was taken from the farm one evening when the boy and I were out scouting the hills. Nothing we could have done about it.
Them creatures have never shown any interest in taking folk before... I'm not even sure why they should start now. Dergiab's behind it for sure, though.
I can only pray that she's all right, yet. I'll get her back, somehow... and then that ogre will pay for all the grief he's caused me.
Maybe you could, at that. I can reward you, if that's what you're keen for. I'll warn you, though... you wouldn't be the first adventurer to head into the hills.
If that's your wish. It's mighty dangerous, after all. If you happen across my wife... or her remains... I'd be glad to know of it.
Same goes if you encounter that Dergiab. I'd pay gold for his head. But I'm sure you've your own matters to attend to, <lad/lass>.
I'd be grateful for it. Find my wife or bring me proof of what's happened to her... and bring me Dergiab's head, if you can. Either would be a great service.
Aye? I'll answer whatever I can, <lad/lass>.
Fair enough. Like I said, I'll give you what reward I can, if you help me out. It's the same offer I've made to any other adventurer that's come by.
I... I certainly hope so, <lad/lass>. It all depends on what Dergiab wants with his prisoners. I've braced myself for the worst, to be honest.
A cult? You mean in connection to Dergiab and these creatures? Hmm. Can't say that I do, really... though that'd explain Dergiab's sudden ambition.
To be honest, I always thought Dergiab fashioned himself as a bit of a god amongst them other monsters. I'd be surprised if he allied with anyone else. You never know, however.
There's a few of them spread out in the hills. They all connect together underground in a large warren, however... be sure you don't get lost.
There's one entrance in the hills just north of here. Most like Dergiab's followers will find you before you find them.
Well, he's an ogre mage... smarter than his brutish cousins and a fair bit more powerful, too. He can become invisible and has plenty of spells, I'd say.
Dergiab's led a lot of the other creatures for quite some time, now. Never been brave enough to really do anything drastic, however... I'm not sure why he would start now.
To be honest, I haven't much left from my adventuring days. I'd be happy to offer what gold I have, though, to have some proof of what happened to my wife... or, better yet, to have her returned.
I'd also offer gold for Dergiab's head, to know for sure that he won't be pestering anyone else in these parts. I know it's not much... chances are Dergiab will have plenty to loot, himself.
Aye, a few have passed this way and headed into the hills to check out the creatures for themselves. None have returned, I'm afraid to say.
Farming, mostly. Though to be perfectly honest, there hasn't been much of that since this area became so dangerous.
It wasn't always this way, of course. In recent days it seems like the entire north is under siege. All us common folk can try to do is help each other as much as we can.
He did, did he? He's a fine lad, he is. I expect, then, that you're some manner of adventurer that he thought could help us, aye?
I didn't mean to imply that you'd agreed to anything, <lad/lass>. I'm just pleased that you've come. Let me explain what's been happening, here.
It's a dangerous thing to ask of anyone, but it might be worth your while, <lad/lass>. Let me fill you in, in case the boy didn't.
Well, now, that's a bit of a tale. I'm surprised the boy didn't fill you in.
Me think you cannot stop me! Me get through gates!
I'm going through those gates - and you!
I'll tell you right now, though... you go inside the city, we ain't letting you back out. In or out, one or the other.
We got a live one!
Hmmm... by your description, I think you're the one the sergeant wants to speak to, <sir/madam>.
You not mind... me going.
Nevermind, I'll go.
You just open gates, less talk.
Just open the gates.
Maybe you is right... me comes back.
Maybe you're right... I'll come back.
You just shuts up and open gate.
Don't patronize me. Just open the gate.
Me be okays. Me wants to go in city.
I'll be fine. I want to go in the city.
Me needs to find cult.
I need to find the cult.
Why? What happens in Luskan?
Why? What's going on in Luskan?
Yeah, you lets me in.
Yes, let me inside.
Hmmm. So you're the one Aarin wants me to let in the gates. You look like trouble, if you ask me. You sure you know what you're doing?
So you're the one that Aarin wants to be let into the city, are you? You sure you know what you're doing?
Hmm. I can believe Aarin when he says you're some kind of hero, my <lord/lady>... you do look the type.
Luskan's a mighty dangerous place to walk into, however. You sure you know what you're doing?
Oh? Well, if you change your mind, I'll still be here to let you in. A favor's a favor.
Oh that's the way of it, is it? Good thing for you Aarin is an old friend... a favor is a favor.
Hmm... maybe it ain't my place to comment, but I'm not sure you're exactly ready for what's going on in there.
You might want to consider getting some better gear and some more experience, first, lest the city tear you apart.
Fair enough. When you feel more prepared, I'll still be here to let you in. A favor is a favor.
All right... the gates are open for you, now. Just remember: I can't let you back out once you're in. Make sure you have everything you need, you hear?
Aye, Aarin mentioned something along those lines. Had plenty of questions about the wizards in the tower, too.
Truth be told, the less I know about what you're up to, the better I'll feel. Do you want inside or not?
Fighting, and lots of it. The High Captains are at war... have been for weeks, now. Luskan's just about torn apart.
I'm sure you're full of questions, but I really can't chat. I promised Aarin a favor, and I'll do it... so do you want inside or not?
The gate's open for you. Just remember: once you go into Luskan, you can't come back out... period. So get everything you need before you go in.
North: Luskan, South: Port Llast
Do not be alarmed, <FirstName>, in any case. I have my orders, just as you do. I will see you in Luskan.
Die, fleshling!
*chitter* *chitter*
*HOOOOOWL*
TAG! You're it!
Uh... I can't talk to you right now, <mister/missus>.
This man twitches with fear at the slightest sound or movement. His whole body quivers with anxiety.
This dwarf's arms bulge with muscles from years of hammering at the forge.
Blacksmith
This half-orc deckhand trudges around the docks, muttering under his breath as he works.
This human has the look of one carried away in religious fervor.
This old man has an air of nervousness and forgetfulness.
This armed and armoured fighter carries himself with assured confidence.
This man staggers around with the reek of cheap ale on his breath.
This sailor walks with a swagger as he whistles an old sea shanty.
This little child seems filled with boundless energy.
This man's facial expressions shift constantly between determined and purpose-filled, to vacant and confused looking.
Between the facial ticks and the wandering eyes, there is something very wrong with this person.
This creature is little more than a shadow, at least to look at.
Shadowy Figure
Forged from solid iron, the crafting of these mighty juggernauts often requires the expertise and master craftwork of either dwarven blacksmiths or gnomish tinkers.
A bitter look from this halfling is all that anyone seems to get.
This little gnome smirks and chuckles to himself as he works.
This customer waits with eager anticipation for something exciting to happen.
This arrogant-looking elf waits impatiently for something to happen.
An elderly, yet commanding man, this is plainly a wizard of immense power. Despite that, he seems a little addled.
This statue of a dwarf is surprisingly life-like in detail.
This woman looks terrified and cold.
This warrior looks like he is ready to battle entire hordes of orcs and goblins.
Goblin Archer
This dwarf eyes the others in the room as if gauging, then dismissing each of them.
This waitress looks exhausted from running around, serving the large crowd of customers who gather in here.
This eager elf is collecting the fees for entrants who wish to begin the contest.
This gnome has a pleasant, though shy smile for just about everyone.
Luskan Sergeant
There is something not quite right about this child.
There is something not quite right about this dwarf.
There is something strange about this old man.
This innkeeper eyes the large crowd with a mixed reaction of pleasure and distrust.
This half-orc, like so many before him, looks like he has a habit of cleaving others in two.
Orc Archer
This halfling looks busy, running errands for a man over in the corner of the inn.
This warrior looks like she is ready to battle entire hordes of orcs and goblins.
This halfling's eyes are blank and his face is set in an unnatural smile.
Aribeth looks tired, distracted, and far more guarded than she did the first time you met her.
This fierce-looking creature is different from anything else found in the realms. Its reptilian features are both frightening and savage.
Deep wrinkles surround the perpetual frown on this man's face.
Caliandros
A worried frown covers this commoner's face as she goes about her business.
A worried frown covers this commoner's face as he goes about his business.
This is a man who measures each step with the smooth grace of a stalking panther. His eyes shift around the room with an intense awareness.
This rough, burly-looking man has a confident, almost cocky air about him.
This young man appears to be rather nervous and shaken.
This serious-looking elf eyes everything with an intense, piercing gaze.
The dwarf sits at a table, rubbing one of his legs in between sips of ale.
An impecibly-dressed elf with silver hair, stands casually near a table. He looks like he could spring into action at a second's notice.
This glassy-eyed lady stares into the sky with a contemplative gaze.
This energetic, young child seems to have endless energy.
This commoner goes about her business with a capable air.
This lively, young child seems to have endless energy.
This commoner goes about his business with a capable air.
This man brow is wrinkled, as if he has carried the weight of the world for a long time now.
Revenants are vengeful spirits that have risen in a decayed version of their earlier bodies so that they can find and destroy their killers.
This gnome carries himself with an aura of holiness and dignity.
This intense looking man stares off into nothing, seemingly lost in deep contemplation.
This beautiful young lass sneers as she looks at other townsfolk, then smiles when she sees you.
This young girl looks truly miserable and frightened.
This woman glares around the tavern, staring down any unfortunate male who happens to look her way.
This is a shifty-eyed gnome who would look suspicious saying prayers in a temple, let alone here.
This elf exudes the extremely confident air of one who has never known defeat.
This man sits and stares at a woman, oblivious to the drool running down his chin.
There is nothing pleasant about the smile on this ranger's face. Malevolent hatred is the only description that could fit.
This half-orc looks and acts more intelligent than his orcish relations in the area. He obviously dominates them.
With grim determination, this warrior carries himself with the strain of controlled violence. You pity the cult member who runs into this soldier.
This cheerful lass stands in your room, eyeing you with an eager anticipation.
The innkeep survey's his customers with a professional eye, watching for thirsty customers with a full purse.
This elderly female is surrounded by some sort of glowing energy field.
This is a hard, angry-looking man. There is a barely controlled rage behind his eyes.
This frightened man looks thin and weak. His clothes are torn to shreds and he bears several wounds.
Despite numerous days of being a prisoner, this elf looks stunning, and she seems to know it.
This older gentleman has the kind of ready-to-spring look of a wild animal.
This vicious, little halfling looks to be seeking a fight.
This halfling druid looks like he could run through the bushes like a fox chasing a rabbit.
This ghostly figure shifts between raging anger and sad desperation as it hovers near a large tree.
This frustrated elf looks like he has been pacing here for a long time.
This man exudes a sense of great power, rooted in the primal forces of nature.
Though dwarven druids are rather rare, the few who choose this path can be quite imtimidating.
With a rough and tumble grin, this half-orc looks ready to fight an army by himself.
Smiling and humming a little tune to herself, this well-muscled woman has an air of quiet confidence.
This elven woman presents a powerful, intimidating front, that leaves no question of her authority.
This young druid has an eager, excited look about him.
This mangy-looking dwarf, wanders around, chanting strange things to himself.
Eyes blank and feverish, this man is obviously under some kind of charm.
This man has a blank but pleased look on his face.
This woman moves with a lack of awareness and confusion on her face.
This elf's calm composure could come across as arrogant if it weren't for the gentle smile on his face.
This beautiful woman has a proud, almost arrogant look about her, that detracts from an almost perfect face.
This ancient creature is almost too unbearably hideous to look at.
This guard wanders around with a slightly confused and dazed look on his face.
This spirit appears to be agitated and quite fearful.
This well-armed halfling looks like he takes life too seriously, or perhaps like he seriously enjoys taking lives.
Deadly looking halflings may not be common, but this one certainly falls into that category.
A brutal, cruel-looking gnome, with an eye out for trouble.
This barmaid looks exhausted from running around, serving the large crowd of customers who gather in here.
This farmer's brow is furrowed in worry and desperation.
Drex'liggarr
This young woman shows concern on her face as she goes about her chores.
This lad has all the markings of a sullen youth.
This well-to-do farmer goes about his business with a brisk efficiency.
Worgs are powerful wolves with an evil disposition and an uncanny intelligence. They are sometimes found with goblins, whom they serve as mounts and guardians.
Drool dribbles off the lips of this man, who's eyes are brimming over with tears.
This is a small and unadorned key.

This katana is a fine blade... it is doubtful that it was forged by human hands, but the only hint as to its origins are the runes along its hilt. These indicate that the precious weapon was enchanted within the walls of the Host Tower of the Arcane. Fire occasionally flares along its cruel edge... this blade has been used often by warriors of great skill in the service of their wizards.

This katana is a fine weapon, obviously kept well-maintained by its owner. It gleams with constant polish. There are no hints as to its origin other than the series of small runes inscribes along its handle.
This squishy little thing is an eyeball from an abyssal Imp.
This small eyeball came from one of the small baatezu Quasits.
This is a large, light key that would seem likely to open the gate doors to Luskan.

This is an official-looking document describing the bearer as an ambassador from the far-off state of Mulhorand, allowing admittance into the Host Tower of Luskan. The document is affixed with the seal of the Arcane Brotherhood.

A letter; the hand writing is blood stained but part of it is legible:
"Dear Amatia:
These caves are deep and dangerous; we've found layers and layers of caves - but there is construction down at the bottom, and the crypts we seek.
We tried to get Darius out, but barely escaped ourselves. We're going back tomorrow, love, to try again; I hope I'll get a chance to send this to you."

I find I've grown fond of the monsters in these caves. They are savage, violent, and easily whipped into a frenzy by my puppet ogre mage Dergiab. Not entirely unlike the rest of us who have turned following Maugrim into a religion... He the puppeteer, we his willing puppets.
And to think he sent me here to search for some ancient artifact as he sent my brothers to Charwood and the Neverwinter Wood. It isn't in this place. It would have left some tell-tale sign. It would want to be found. It would call me to it. Perhaps they have had better luck in the two Woods. So, instead of being a puppet, I have become the puppeteer. Not so grand as Maugrim but, even so, look how Dergiab struts and schemes at my bidding...
Rogue Outfit

South Road: Peter and the Wolves

Pete O'Deel, a cattle rancher in the plains fair south of Port Llast, is having trouble with some wolves that have moved into the area. He's given the leader of the pack the name of Silverback and is offering a reward for her head. Silverback apparently makes her den in a cave just past the uppermost waterfall near Pete's home.

Pete O'Deel, a cattle rancher in the plains fair south of Port Llast, is having trouble with some wolves that have moved into the area. He's given the leader of the pack the name of Silverback and is offering a reward for her head.
Silverback dens in a cave just past the uppermost waterfall near Pete's home and, strangely enough, she can speak common thanks to the efforts of a cruel ranger who was her mother's master. She has been persuaded to no longer prey on Pete's cattle but Pete still needs to be convinced that his herd will be safe.

Pete O'Deel, a cattle rancher in the plains fair south of Port Llast, was having trouble with some wolves that had moved into the area. The leader of the pack, a she-wolf named Silverback, has been persuaded to no longer prey on Pete's cattle. Unfortunately, Pete seems unwilling to compromise on the matter and continues to call for Silverback's head.

Pete O'Deel, a cattle rancher in the plains fair south of Port Llast, was having trouble with some wolves that had moved into the area. The leader of the pack, a she-wolf named Silverback, has been persuaded to no longer prey on Pete's cattle, a compromise that Pete seemed more than willing to settle for.

Pete O'Deel, a cattle rancher in the plains fair south of Port Llast, is having trouble with some wolves that have moved into the area. He's given the leader of the pack the name of Silverback and is offering a reward for her head. Silverback has now been killed and her head needs to be returned to Pete for the promised reward.

Pete O'Deel, a cattle rancher in the plains fair south of Port Llast, was having trouble with some wolves that had moved into the area. He gave the leader of the pack the name of Silverback and offered a reward for her head. When the she-wolf's head was finally presented to him, he was true to his word and gave the promised reward.
South Road: The Brooch of Erik's Ma
Ingo, a farmer in the plains far south of Port Llast, claims, with a degree of frustration, that his son has locked himself in his room after a failed courtship with a local girl.

Erik, son of Ingo who farms in the plains far south of Port Llast, has foolishly given the brooch of his deceased mother to a young woman he had been courting. Not wanting to face his father's wrath, Erik is desperate to get the brooch back, offering to reward anyone who can deliver it to him. The young woman in question is Constance O'Deel, whose father raises cattle on the nearby southern bluffs.

Erik, son of Ingo who farms in the plains far south of Port Llast, had foolishly given the brooch of his deceased mother to Constance O'Deel, a young woman he had been courting. The brooch has now been recovered and Erik would be extremely grateful for its return.

Erik, son of Ingo who farms in the plains far south of Port Llast, had foolishly given the brooch of his deceased mother to Constance O'Deel, a young woman he had been courting. The brooch has now been returned to him in exchange for a substantial reward.
Charwood: The Village of Eternal Night

The strange village of Charwood is buried deep within the forest that shares its name. It is shrouded by sheets of deep blue mist and seems to exist beneath a pall of endless night. At the entrance, a madman by the name of Quint greets newcomers with riddles before disappearing in a puff of blood-drenched smoke.

The strange village of Charwood is buried deep within the forest that shares its name. It is shrouded by sheets of deep blue mist and seems to exist beneath a pall of endless night. At the entrance, a madman by the name of Quint greets newcomers with riddles before disappearing in a puff of blood-drenched smoke. Inside the village proper, the townsfolk seem to be lost in a haze of confusion and forgetfulness, repeating their words endlessly into the chill night air. The only useful suggestion they can offer is to talk to the Mayor in the Town Hall.

The strange village of Charwood is buried deep within the forest that shares its name. It is shrouded by sheets of deep blue mist and seems to exist beneath a pall of endless night. At the entrance, a madman by the name of Quint greets newcomers with riddles before disappearing in a puff of blood-drenched smoke. Inside the village proper, the townsfolk seem to be lost in a haze of confusion and forgetfulness, repeating their words endlessly into the chill night air. The Mayor is no different, though he seems frightened by the prospect of anyone entering the forboding Castle Jhareg which looms over the settlement's north edge.

The strange village of Charwood is buried deep within the forest that shares its name. It is shrouded by sheets of deep blue mist and seems to exist beneath a pall of endless night. At the entrance, a madman by the name of Quint greets newcomers with riddles before disappearing in a puff of blood-drenched smoke. Inside the village proper, the townsfolk seem to be lost in a haze of confusion and forgetfulness, repeating their words endlessly into the chill night air. The Mayor is no different, though he seems frightened by the prospect of anyone entering the forboding Castle Jhareg which looms over the settlement's north edge.
Inside the castle, one is met with three doors and but a single key. A note tied to the key speaks of Judgment and suggests that the three doors represent three different paths of Justice.

The strange village of Charwood is buried deep within the forest that shares its name. It is shrouded by sheets of deep blue mist and seems to exist beneath a pall of endless night. At the entrance, a madman by the name of Quint greets newcomers with riddles before disappearing in a puff of blood-drenched smoke. Inside the village proper, the townsfolk seem to be lost in a haze of confusion and forgetfulness, repeating their words endlessly into the chill night air. The Mayor is no different, though he seems frightened by the prospect of anyone entering the forboding Castle Jhareg which looms over the settlement's north edge.
Inside the castle, one is met with three doors and but a single key. A note tied to the key speaks of Judgment and suggests that the three doors represent three different paths of Justice. Further in, one is met by a Guardian Spirit who claims that Lathander, god of the morning, has allowed this place to slip between the weave of time, pending the arrival of someone willing to stand in Judgment over the two brothers, Quint and Karlat Jhareg, who are said to have been involved in some horrendous, though unspoken crime. Karlat is said to be confined within the western tower while Quint, the madman at the gate, is supposedly confined within the eastern tower. Whoever wishes to stand in Judgment must learn what facts they can of the case, obtain the written oaths of these two brothers, and present them to the Guardian Spirit.

The strange village of Charwood is buried deep within the forest that shares its name. It is shrouded by sheets of deep blue mist and seems to exist beneath a pall of endless night. At the entrance, a madman by the name of Quint greets newcomers with riddles before disappearing in a puff of blood-drenched smoke. Inside the village proper, the townsfolk seem to be lost in a haze of confusion and forgetfulness, repeating their words endlessly into the chill night air. The Mayor is no different, though he seems frightened by the prospect of anyone entering the forboding Castle Jhareg which looms over the settlement's north edge.
Inside the castle, one is met with three doors and but a single key. A note tied to the key speaks of Judgment and suggests that the three doors represent three different paths of Justice. Further in, one is met by a Guardian Spirit who claims that Lathander, god of the morning, has allowed this place to slip between the weave of time, pending the arrival of someone willing to stand in Judgment over the two brothers, Quint and Karlat Jhareg, who are said to have been involved in some horrendous, though unspoken crime. Karlat is said to be confined within the western tower while Quint, the madman at the gate, is supposedly confined within the eastern tower. Whoever wished to stand in Judgment had to learn what facts they could of the case, obtain the written oaths of these two brothers, and present them to the Guardian Spirit.
This has all now come to pass and the Judge has arrived at a decision. The half-lich, Karlat Jhareg, has been declared guilty of the slaughter of the children of Charwood. As a result, the phylactery that Quint had stolen from him is to be destroyed, putting an end to Karlat's unlife, freeing the souls trapped within this place, and returning Charwood to the weave of time.

The strange village of Charwood is buried deep within the forest that shares its name. It is shrouded by sheets of deep blue mist and seems to exist beneath a pall of endless night. At the entrance, a madman by the name of Quint greets newcomers with riddles before disappearing in a puff of blood-drenched smoke. Inside the village proper, the townsfolk seem to be lost in a haze of confusion and forgetfulness, repeating their words endlessly into the chill night air. The Mayor is no different, though he seems frightened by the prospect of anyone entering the forboding Castle Jhareg which looms over the settlement's north edge.
Inside the castle, one is met with three doors and but a single key. A note tied to the key speaks of Judgment and suggests that the three doors represent three different paths of Justice. Further in, one is met by a Guardian Spirit who claims that Lathander, god of the morning, has allowed this place to slip between the weave of time, pending the arrival of someone willing to stand in Judgment over the two brothers, Quint and Karlat Jhareg, who are said to have been involved in some horrendous, though unspoken crime. Karlat is said to be confined within the western tower while Quint, the madman at the gate, is supposedly confined within the eastern tower. Whoever wished to stand in Judgment had to learn what facts they could of the case, obtain the written oaths of these two brothers, and present them to the Guardian Spirit.
This has all now come to pass and the Judge has arrived at a decision. The madman and former cleric of Lathander, Quint Jhareg, has been declared guilty of the slaughter of the children of Charwood. As a result, the phylactery he had stolen so long ago has now been returned to his brother, Karlat, who will use it to become a baelnorn and return Charwood to the weave of time.

The strange village of Charwood is buried deep within the forest that shares its name. It is shrouded by sheets of deep blue mist and seems to exist beneath a pall of endless night. At the entrance, a madman by the name of Quint greets newcomers with riddles before disappearing in a puff of blood-drenched smoke. Inside the village proper, the townsfolk seem to be lost in a haze of confusion and forgetfulness, repeating their words endlessly into the chill night air. The Mayor is no different, though he seems frightened by the prospect of anyone entering the forboding Castle Jhareg which looms over the settlement's north edge.
Inside the castle, one is met with three doors and but a single key. A note tied to the key speaks of Judgment and suggests that the three doors represent three different paths of Justice. Further in, one is met by a Guardian Spirit who claims that Lathander, god of the morning, has allowed this place to slip between the weave of time, pending the arrival of someone willing to stand in Judgment over the two brothers, Quint and Karlat Jhareg, who are said to have been involved in some horrendous, though unspoken crime. Karlat is said to be confined within the western tower while Quint, the madman at the gate, is supposedly confined within the eastern tower. Whoever wished to stand in Judgment had to learn what facts they could of the case, obtain the written oaths of these two brothers, and present them to the Guardian Spirit.
This has all now come to pass and the Judge has arrived at a decision. Based on a third oath provided by the demon Belial, Lord of Fire, both of the brothers Jhareg have been declared innocent of the slaughter of the children of Charwood. The only means of punishing the demon, however, was to return the phylactery to the Guardian Spirit that she might protect it for all eternity. As a result, Charwood will forever remain outside the weave of time and all of its inhabitants, guilty and innocent alike, will be cursed to remain forever trapped within its mists.

The strange village of Charwood is buried deep within the forest that shares its name. It is shrouded by sheets of deep blue mist and seems to exist beneath a pall of endless night. At the entrance, a madman by the name of Quint greets newcomers with riddles before disappearing in a puff of blood-drenched smoke. Inside the village proper, the townsfolk seem to be lost in a haze of confusion and forgetfulness, repeating their words endlessly into the chill night air. The Mayor is no different, though he seems frightened by the prospect of anyone entering the forboding Castle Jhareg which looms over the settlement's north edge.
Inside the castle, one is met with three doors and but a single key. A note tied to the key speaks of Judgment and suggests that the three doors represent three different paths of Justice. Further in, one is met by a Guardian Spirit who claims that Lathander, god of the morning, has allowed this place to slip between the weave of time, pending the arrival of someone willing to stand in Judgment over the two brothers, Quint and Karlat Jhareg, who are said to have been involved in some horrendous, though unspoken crime. Karlat is said to be confined within the western tower while Quint, the madman at the gate, is supposedly confined within the eastern tower. Whoever wished to stand in Judgment had to learn what facts they could of the case, obtain the written oaths of these two brothers, and present them to the Guardian Spirit.
This has all now come to pass and the Judge has arrived at a decision. Based on a third oath provided by the demon Belial, Lord of Fire, both of the brothers Jhareg have been declared innocent of the slaughter of the children of Charwood. Seeing no way to punish Belial without also punishing the other spirits trapped within the village, the Judge opted to take possession of the phylactery and forever stand guard over it. As a result, the citizens of Charwood, Belial included, will at last be set free and the village will be returned to the weave of time where it belongs.
Charwood: Quint's Tale

Quint Jhareg, one of the two lords of Charwood who currently stand accused by the Guardian Spirit on the castle's main floor, has been discovered in a cell within his eastern tower. The former cleric of Lathander now seems quite mad and very much plagued by guilt over the death of the village children within this castle so long ago. Quint readily admits to gethering the children into the castle on midwinter's eve so long ago and also to stealing his brother's phylactery. He has begged that he be punished for his crimes.

The journal of Quint Jhareg, one of the two lords of Charwood who currently stand accused by the Guardian Spirit on the castle's main floor, has been discovered in the eastern tower. If it is to be believed, Quint was quite innocent of the crimes committed and genuinely fond of the village children who were ultimately slaughtered within the castle's walls. If anything, the journal suggests that Quint might have been manipulated by his older brother who wanted the children gathered for some darker purpose.

Quint Jhareg, one of the two lords of Charwood who currently stand accused by the Guardian Spirit on the castle's main floor, has been discovered in a cell within his eastern tower. The former cleric of Lathander now seems quite mad and very much plagued by guilt over the death of the village children within this castle so long ago. Quint readily admits to gethering the children into the castle on midwinter's eve so long ago and also to stealing his brother's phylactery. He has begged that he be punished for his crimes.
Quint has now provided a written oath stating that the above is true. This oath should be submitted to the Guardian Spirit as evidence.

The journal of Quint Jhareg, one of the two lords of Charwood who currently stand accused by the Guardian Spirit on the castle's main floor, has been discovered in the eastern tower. If it is to be believed, Quint was quite innocent of the crimes committed and genuinely fond of the village children who were ultimately slaughtered within the castle's walls. If anything, the journal suggests that Quint might have been manipulated by his older brother who wanted the children gathered for some darker purpose.
Quint has now provided a written oath stating that the above is true. This oath should be submitted to the Guardian Spirit as evidence.
Charwood: Karlat's Tale

Karlat Jhareg, one of the two lords of Charwood who currently stand accused by the Guardian Spirit on the castle's main floor, has been discovered in a cell within his west tower. He has the skeletal form of a half-lich, though he claims that the end result of his long-interrupted ritual will be to become a baelnorn, a noble and highly respected type of lich within elven tradition. He blames the slaughter of the village children on his maddened brother, Quint, who he also accuses of stealing an all-important magical phylactery, thereby interrupting Karlat's ritual and trapping the spirits of everyone in the area.

The journal of Karlat Jhareg, one of the two lords of Charwood who currently stand accused by the Guardian Spirit on the castle's main floor, has been discovered in the western tower. If it is to be believed, Karlat tricked his brother into inviting the village children into the castle for a party on midwinter's eve. On the advice of a summoned demon, Karlat plotted to slaughter the children in order to further his ambitions of becoming a lich.

Karlat Jhareg, one of the two lords of Charwood who currently stand accused by the Guardian Spirit on the castle's main floor, has been discovered in a cell within his west tower. He has the skeletal form of a half-lich, though he claims that the end result of his long-interrupted ritual will be to become a baelnorn, a noble and highly respected type of lich within elven tradition. He blames the slaughter of the village children on his maddened brother, Quint, who he also accuses of stealing an all-important magical phylactery, thereby interrupting Karlat's ritual and trapping the spirits of everyone in the area.
Karlat has now provided a written oath stating that the above is true. This oath should be submitted to the Guardian Spirit as evidence.

The journal of Karlat Jhareg, one of the two lords of Charwood who currently stand accused by the Guardian Spirit on the castle's main floor, has been discovered in the western tower. If it is to be believed, Karlat tricked his brother into inviting the village children into the castle for a party on midwinter's eve. On the advice of a summoned demon, Karlat plotted to slaughter the children in order to further his ambitions of becoming a lich.
Karlat has now provided a written oath stating that the above is true. This oath should be submitted to the Guardian Spirit as evidence.
Charwood: Belial's Tale

A large book has been discovered in the tower of Karlat Jhareg, one of the two lords of Charwood who currently stand accused by the Guardian Spirit on the castle's main floor. Lighting the nearby candelabra revealed instructions regarding the summoning of the demon Belial, Lord of Fire. A demon's influence in these events seems suspicious and well worth investigating, though a re-summoning is no doubt risky business.

The demon Belial, Lord of Fire, has been re-summoned to Castle Jhareg's haunted halls to present further evidence in the case of the brothers Jhareg. The two lords of Charwood stand accused of an unspeakable crime by the Guardian Spirit on the castle's main floor and she would no doubt be interested in seeing the written oath that Belial has so recently provided.
According to the demon's account, he lied to Karlat, his original summoner, claiming the slaughter of the village children was necessary if the sorcerer was to become a baelnorn. Belial appears quite proud of this tragic subterfuge, flaunting it readily. He does not fear Judgment, as any return to the Abyss will be a triumphal homecoming for him. It would be wise to consider this evidence carefully.

A large book has been discovered in the tower of Karlat Jhareg, one of the two lords of Charwood who currently stand accused by the Guardian Spirit on the castle's main floor. Lighting the nearby candelabra revealed instructions regarding the summoning of the demon Belial, Lord of Fire. A demon's influence in these events seemed suspicious and well worth investigating, so a re-summoning was attempted.
Unfortunately, the summoning was squandered and no viable evidence could be obtained from the Lord of Fire.
Port Llast: The Werewolf Hunter

Neurik, a priest of Tyr who presides of Port Llast's temple, warns of a terrible tragedy that has befallen some of the town's young men. Sir Karathis Ironheart, a travelling werewolf hunter, enlisted the help of four boys to hunt a foul lycanthrope known only as the Black Wolf. It was a trap, however, and Sir Karathis was himself the Black Wolf. His claws raked the flesh of Bran, Urth, and Geth, infecting them with his dread disease, leaving only the youngest boy, Ander, to escape. Neurik believes that, if found soon enough, the three young men may still be curable by a potion he has concocted. Ander currently spends his days at the Alliance Arms Inn, trying to spread news amongst adventurers of the tragedy that befell his friends. Neurik recommends speaking with the boy to gain an understanding of where those friends may now be hiding.

Neurik, a priest of Tyr who presides of Port Llast's temple, warns of a terrible tragedy that has befallen some of the town's young men. Sir Karathis Ironheart, a travelling werewolf hunter, enlisted the help of four boys to hunt a foul lycanthrope known only as the Black Wolf. It was a trap, however, and Sir Karathis was himself the Black Wolf. His claws raked the flesh of Bran, Urth, and Geth, infecting them with his dread disease, leaving only the youngest boy, Ander, to escape. Neurik believes that, if found soon enough, the three young men may still be curable by a potion he has concocted.
Ander, who currently spends his days at the Alliance Arms Inn, trying to spread news amongst adventurers of the tragedy that befell his friends, has a few guesses as to where his friends might have fled. He suspects that Bran is somewhere along the road to Charwood and Geth might be taking refuge in the Neverwinter Wood. Ander wasn't sure about Urth but recommended talking to his parents who live on the edge of town. The last time Ander saw Sir Karathis, it was at the supposed cave of the Black Wolf, in the hills east of the Green Griffon Inn.

One of the boys has been discovered. Neurik will be interested in examining the adventuring ring that Sir Karathis had given the boy, in case it can reveal any further clues as to the supposed werewolf hunter's whereabouts.

Ander wasn't sure about Urth but recommended talking to his parents who live on the edge of town. The last time Ander saw Sir Karathis, it was at the supposed cave of the Black Wolf, in the hills east of the Green Griffon Inn.
All three of the boys have been discovered. Neurik will be interested in examining the adventuring rings that Sir Karathis had gave the boys. Perhaps it is time to revisit the scene of the initial tragedy to discover whether or not Sir Karathis still lingers there.

It appears that Sir Karathis Ironheart is not the Black Wolf after all. He entered the caves east of the Green Griffon Inn and was ambushed and infected himself. Maddened with the bloodlust of his unexpected transformation, he lashed out at the boys who had joined him in the hunt but luckily was able to refrain from killing them outright. Neurik, the Tyrist priest back in Port Llast was chagrined to learn that, even with the situation of Sir Karathis addressed, the dreaded Black Wolf remains on the loose. Worse yet, Sir Karathis has given him a familiar name: Alhelor, the merchant selling anti-lycanthropic supplies at Ander's side in Port Llast's Alliance Arms Inn. The boy's life is in great danger and Neurik has given the order to find and destroy Alhelor at once.

It appears that Sir Karathis Ironheart is not the Black Wolf after all. He entered the caves east of the Green Griffon Inn and was ambushed and infected himself. Maddened with the bloodlust of his unexpected transformation, he lashed out at the boys who had joined him in the hunt but luckily was able to refrain from killing them outright. Neurik, the Tyrist priest back in Port Llast was chagrined to learn that, even with the situation of Sir Karathis addressed, the dreaded Black Wolf remains on the loose. The boy's life is in great danger and Neurik has given the order to find and destroy Alhelor at once.
Luckily Ander is safe and sound in the Alliance Arms Inn. Alhelor appears to have caught wind of the recent news, however, and has supposedly retired to his home in the town's northeast corner. Given his previous ambush Sir Karathis, it would be wise to porceed with caution.

It appears that Sir Karathis Ironheart is not the Black Wolf after all. He entered the caves east of the Green Griffon Inn and was ambushed and infected himself. Maddened with the bloodlust of his unexpected transformation, he lashed out at the boys who had joined him in the hunt but luckily was able to refrain from killing them outright. Worse yet, Sir Karathis has given him a familiar name: Alhelor, the merchant who sold anti-lycanthropic supplies at Ander's side in Port Llast's Alliance Arms Inn. Luckily Ander was discovered safe and sound, though Alhelor had caught wind of the recent news and fled the inn. He was tracked down to his home, however, and finally killed. Neurik, the town priest, would be grateful to see Alhelor's tooth which has already been recovered as evidence of the deed.

The boy's life is in great danger and it is imperative that this news be reported to Neurik at once.
Port Llast: The Serpent's Gems

The infamous adventurer, Elaith "The Serpent" Craulnober appears to have at last become homesick for the land of Evereska he fled so long ago. He and his daughter are currently staying at an inn in Port Llast, searching for three gems that will help them make the journey home. Unfortunately, the gems are not in the hands of people interested in parting easily with them.
The first is in the possession of a local wizard by the name of Wanev. He lives in his tower south of town. The second is held by the warrior Zamithra who recently passed through Port Llast on her way to Luskan. The final gem is the personal treasure of Setara, a witch of the Neverwinter Wood.

One of these gems has now been discovered.

The famed adventurer, Elaith "The Serpent" Craulnober appears to have at last become homesick for the land of Evereska he fled so long ago. He and his daughter are currently staying at an inn in Port Llast, searching for three gems that will help them make the journey home. All of them have been recovered, however, and the pair has now sailed the stars back to their homeland.
Port Llast: Bounty Hunt

Kendrack, head of the mercenary guild and Mayor of Port Llast, has put out a reward for the death of five dangerous prisoners escaped from Waterdeep. They have separated to avoid detection but can all be identified by means of a tattoo on their left ear, marking them as inmates of the Bulwark prison. It is this tattoo that Kendrack wants as evidence of the deed.
Zor, a burly minotaur, is rumored to be hiding with friends and contacts he has in Luskan. Wyvern, an elven ranger with a taste for trickery, will likely have sought refuge in the Neverwinter Wood. Stirge, an egomaniacal gnome, was last sighted on the road south of Port Llast. Delilah, a halfling assassin who once made her home in Luskan, has probably returned there. Yesgar, the group's ring-leader and mastermind, remains elusive though Kendrack doubts that he'd stray far.

Yesgar, the group's ring-leader and mastermind, remains elusive though Kendrack doubts that he'd stray far.
Thus far, adventurers have acquired only one ear of the five.
